COLMES: I'd like to see him move faster on some things. He inherited a nightmare from the previous administration.

IMUS: Oh, well, you can't spend the rest of your life blaming that incompetent buffoon who was the president before this guy.

COLMES: You've got to sweep up the mess that was left.

IMUS: Well, yes, but grab a mop and get busy then, as he said.

COLMES: What do you think he's doing? He was just praised for going to Dover Air Force Base. That's change you can believe.

IMUS: That's one thing he did that was good.

MCCORD: Symbolic.

IMUS: I like the guy, by the way. I mean, Sean Hannity, it makes him insane when I say that, but I do like him. But I don't think he has any idea what he's doing, and he's more interested in being president...

COLMES: Oh, that's just ridiculous.

IMUS: ... spending five hours playing golf with that dope Tom Friedman.

COLMES: I'm with O'Reilly on this one. The guy's not allowed to have a golf game?

IMUS: No, not to...

COLMES: The guy can't go enjoy himself for a few hours?

IMUS: No, no, not to -- no, come on. Do you have five hours to go play -- you probably do, but I don't have five hours to go do anything.

COLMES: Wait a minute. So, when George W. Bush said, "I'm playing through" after he was talking about the tragedy of 9/11, that was OK, right?

IMUS: Well, I didn't say it was OK.

(CROSSTALK)

IMUS: I didn't vote for him. I didn't vote for him either time. What are you talking about?

COLMES: Well, I'm just pointing out to your audience the hypocrisy there.

IMUS: Pardon me?

COLMES: I'm pointing out the hypocrisy in the situation.

IMUS: Well, it's completely lost on me, and now you've irritated me. So...

COLMES: Oh, I'm really sorry.

IMUS: No you're not. You don't care at all.

COLMES: I don't know how I can make it up to you.

IMUS: You don't care about me.

COLMES: Yes, I do.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

IMUS: Tonight at 6:00 p.m. Eastern Time on the Fox Business Network, Neil Cavuto will interview our new favorite fat boy, New Jersey gubernatorial candidate Chris Christie.

And speaking of -- well, not fat boys, but Cavuto -- but then we could make a case for -- well, whatever. He'll be on this program tomorrow morning, along with Mike Lupica. He'll be talking about his new book, "Million- Dollar Throw."

Right now, time for "THE OPENING BELL."

END

urn:contentItem:7X14-2090-YC58-81Y9-00000-00Interview with Matt Taibbi; Top Business Headlines; Top News Headlines; Sports Update; Interview With Big Kenny; Interview With Alan2009-11-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:24ZLexisNexisInterview with Matt Taibbi; Top Business Headlines; Top News Headlines; Sports Update; Interview With Big Kenny; Interview With Alan

DON IMUS, HOST: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Time now for a business update from the Fox Business Network. Here is Jenna Lee.

JENNA LEE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Good morning everybody. Hope you had a good weekend. Coming up on IMUS IN THE MORNING.

Country star Big Kenny from Big and Rich Fame will join Imus to talk about his new album, play a little music for us this Monday morning. We are looking forward to that. Let's get to your Fox Business minute.

CIT group filing for bankruptcy, that's the big news today. It's the fifth largest bankruptcy in U.S. history. The lender was not able to get its bondholders to agree to a debt for equity offer but according to the Wall Street Journal CIT does have support for a prepackaged bankruptcy plan including funding from billionaire investor Carl Icahn. That could allow CIT to emerge from bankruptcy by the end of this year.

A big weekend for bank failures as fed sees nine more banks, the most ever to be shed down one day since the financial crisis begin. The banks will reopen today as u.s. Bank branches after the company stepped in and aggress to assume their deposit. This brings the total of bank failures so far this year to 115.

And other banking news executives from the country's 28 largest banks are meeting with Federal Reserve officials today to discuss compensation as well as regulation. The fed is looking to take information from the meeting and get a look at the compensation trends and practices used by the companies.

We also have some breaking earnings news at this hour as well for Humana. It looks like Humana is out with the -- it's earning $1.78 which would beat expectations by a penny. As far as revenue, it looks like revenue is a little bit light, 7.72 which is below the expectation of 7.82. So, keep an eye and Humana today. That's your Fox Business minute.

When you log on this morning. Go download the new Fox Business app, it's the only app that notifies you when your stock hits the target price you want. That's very important and you can do this while you're watching the best business television on the web live, foxbusiness.come/live or online right now to be sure to check us out, foxbusiness.com.

Here's a quick look at European markets. See how they're shaping up this Monday morning. And a quick look at futures as we show you Oil and Gold. imus in the morning is up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

IMUS: Based on the interview that he did yesterday on his program Chris Christie -- if he doesn't get elected government in New Jersey, maybe there is something is wrong.

(CROSSTALK)

IMUS: Politics -- but -- like Corzine is just a slimy, sleazy, Goldman Sachs thief, and an arrogant idiot dirt bag. All of that. But why do we need to get into this name calling, Bernie?

CHARLES MCCORD, HOST: Well, don't hold back here I-man.

IMUS: Here's what I don't like about, when I got fired, you know, and when I was coming back to work, this moron -- I wasn't going to talk about this but I will. He had some statement about what he thought that I ought to have to do to come back to work. And here's what he have to do -- he ought to kiss my ass. How does that sound?

ANNOUNCER: Ladies and Gentlemen, imus in the morning.

IMUS: Third day to my mind Charles.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: I will go down in history. February 15, 2004, when the Yankees traded for A-Rod.

MCCORD: Right.

IMUS: And of course, May 8, 2009, when it came back from a hit a home run.

MCCORD: Just exploded.

IMUS: There was never a doubt in my mind at any point that going back to February 15th, 2004, at the Yankees for marching on their way to the 27th world championship.

BERNARD MCGUIRK, HOST: May I just add rocket propelled to their 27th.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: So, way to go A-Rod.

WARNER WOLF, WARNER SPORT'S HOST: The name of the law (ph).

IMUS: What's the matter Warner?

(ALL TALKING AT ONCE)

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: The fat boy will be on with Cavuto. The next governor of New Jersey, kind of interesting. Whether you like him or not, it's not a decent job, and even if he hasn't, he is not a creep. You know, he figured out a way to put together $16 billion.

MCCORD: Yes, he did.

IMUS: He said to Corzine that he is a moron. And we know Corzine is a creep. And then I was watching the best of Imus, euphemistically speaking of course, on Saturday morning on the Fox Business Network. And half the time when I'm talking to people, I'm checking my e-mail.

MCCORD: I know its ugly reading his e-mail.

IMUS: I mean, it's difficult to get me to listen anyway.

MCCORD: Yes, sure because that's a God damn thing.

IMUS: It is clear I am not listening to a word they are saying. I was talking to Laura Ingram when she was going out her notes word by word and that's people I like.

MCCORD: Stunning that you are able to hold up your end of the conversation.

IMUS: Anyway, coming up this morning, Big Kenny is here.

MCCORD: All right.

IMUS: And he's got his love everybody. And we will be playing that song and we don't love anybody. There is no one.

(LAUGHTER)

MCCORD: Not a knocked on .

IMUS: You know what is new CD Charles?

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: The quiet times of a rock and roll farm boy. Which you can actually plant this thing.

MCCORD: No, you can't.

IMUS: This is way over thinking. No, no, no, it's fine, yes.

MCCORD: Really?

IMUS: But first we want to find out if we can listen to it which I would think.

MCCORD: What happens when you plant it?

IMUS: I don't know.

MCGUIRK: You could smoke it afterward.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: Yes, it grows and you could smoke it, you know.

ROB BARTLETT, COMEDIAN HOST: Hey, man. This is really good.

IMUS: So happy birthday to Big Kenny. It was his birthday yesterday. And his son's name, I think, is not Ford. It is not Chevy. It is Lincoln.

MCCORD: Lincoln, OK.

IMUS: Or Jefferson. No, it's Lincoln. It is Lincoln's birthday today.

MCCORD: Great.

IMUS: So, we got him a little cake. And Cally (ph) said he's already up. He is cranky but, you know, it is 6:00 in the morning in New York.

MCCORD: Sure.

IMUS: Anyway, Jenna Lee is going to have some business news at CIT. A thing that I don't understand at all but who else is doing business stuff?

STAFF: It's Dagen.

IMUS: Dagen McDowell. She will have some information about this as well. Warner Wolf, it is not over, right Warner?

WOLF: No, it's not over. Cliff Lee will win tonight two to nothing. Phillies will shoot out the Yankees two to nothing. Game six in New York on Wednesday.

IMUS: Then it's over.

WOLF: Good day. No, I'm thinking to go seven.

IMUS: Are you down?

WOLF: Yes. This is hopefully at the Seven Game Series.

IMUS: All right.

WOLF: And Charlie Manuel, I mean, I can't understand, he will going to get second guess forever. I don't care about three day's arrest. Cliff Lee had to pitch last night when you are down two games to one.

IMUS: Now you are down three to one.

WOLF: And now, you're down three to one. He had to pitch last night.

IMUS: He's going to pitch tonight?

WOLF: Yes, but if he wins you're still down now three-two. He had to pitch in the fourth game if you trail tow games to one.

IMUS: Well, but he didn't do it.

WOLF: He didn't do it. No.

IMUS: He will going to pitch tonight?

WOLF: Yes, that's right Imus.

IMUS: OK. Let's have to move on.

WOLF: Oh, my God.

(LAUGHTER)

MCCORD: He didn't pitch last night so .

IMUS: He's going first.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: All right. Here's Charles with some news.

MCCORD: An explosion in Pakistan's Rawalpindi City today has killed 20 people at least and wounded more than a dozen and here is a reporter on the scene there.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

reporter (voice-over): A motorcycle ride -- themselves up in a military garrison area. He get detonated the motorcycle just outside a bank where most of the employees of the security services and other civilians had come to either withdraw their salaries or deposit their salary cheques.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCCORD: The explosion took place in the neighborhood not far from the army's main headquarters, Rawalpindi just a few miles away from the capital Islamabad. Suspected militants have now hit Pakistan's several times in recent weeks killing at all around 250 people. And apparent retaliation for the Pakistani army got offensive and the Taliban stronghold in the northwest.

Afghanistan Abdullah Abdullah pulling out of this week's runoff. Secretary of State Clinton says that Mr. Abdullah's announcement does not calling to question the legitimacy of the recent election which President Karzai want with less that 50% of the vote.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HILLARY CLINTON, SECRETARY OF STATE: When President Karzai accepted the second round without knowing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

IMUS: We don't have to be really insulted by that nonsense. What did the Billy (ph) say? I thought the whole thing was a scam and a shame.

MCCORD: And would be again.

IMUS: And would be again, he just .

MCCORD: If he was down in the polls too.

IMUS: Yes, he was.

MCGUIRK: He was reading the -- I got lady and upstate New York who would be humiliated again.

IMUS: Well, I don't know. You think that was it was?

MCGUIRK: Yes.

IMUS: Well, OK. Never mine them.

MCCORD: Abdullah pull out of the run of this weekend after .

IMUS: Oh, let's go back and see what the first -- not the first lady but the secretary had to say.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CLINTON: When President Karzai accepted the second round without knowing what the consequences and outcome would be, that bestowed legitimacy from that moment forward and Dr. Abdullah's decision does not anyway take away from that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

IMUS: That's a very good point.

MCCORD: Very astute.

(CROSSTALK)

IMUS: Congratulations. That's very wonderful secretary of state.

MCCORD: And President Obama's top advisers say he will make a decision, now, quote, "within weeks on whether to send more troops to Afghanistan. They say Obama is going through a rigorous decision-making process because he wants to make sure that we got the strategy right."

IMUS: It is12 minutes after the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Time for the Fox Business Network, business report. Here with us is Dagen McDowell. Good morning Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Good morning sir.

IMUS: How are you?

MCDOWELL: I am fantastic.

IMUS: So, CIT is what? There going bankrupt but -- it's critical, right?

MCDOWELL: All right. No but still a critical part. A lending in this country, it is a 100-year-old lender to small and medium-size businesses and it does this specialty lending and specialty financing in particular retail. So, there are literally hundreds of thousands of retailers and vendors. People have made everything from close to hats that use CIT. Here is what you need to do. The American taxpayer with this bankruptcy just lost $2.3 billion. That's what you need to know. The first lost related to those financial bail-outs last year.

IMUS: You know, I was talking to Bernie while you're talking, so I don't know what you said.

MCDOWELL: OK. You want me to repeat it?

IMUS: No. Do you know what she said Charles?

MCCORD: Yes. I do.

IMUS: What is she saying?

MCCORD: That this thing is the leading provider of financing to retailers and their vendors and Dagen said that the bottom line, we were losing $2.3 billion with this thing going down.

MCDOWELL: Bottom line, American taxpayers just lost $2.3 billion with this bankruptcy.

IMUS: How so?

MCDOWELL: And, because we put money, we the American taxpayer's part of the financial bail out put that money in the CIT last year with the bankruptcy filing the taxpayers lost and this is the first lost, recorded lost from those bail outs that, you know, 400 billion plus bail outs to the financial firm.

IMUS: So, you mean that, they don't have to pay us back?

MCDOWELL: They are not going to pay us back. Right. They do not have to.

IMUS: That was not good.

MCDOWELL: No, that's not good. By the way, you know what? Big Kenny's from my neck of the wood. He's from Virginia.

IMUS: That's great. It's too bad you can't come in the green room, you guys will love all the time.

MCCORD: Oh, that's true.

MCDOWELL: I'll try to stay away from the guest in the green room especially if I they had their make up on.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: No make on? You look fine.

MCDOWELL: OK.

IMUS: Have you come down with -- Van Morrison was there the whole day.

(LAUGHTER)

MCCORD: Another reason to stay away with guests in the green room.

IMUS: Yes, anyway, thanks Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Thank you sir.

IMUS: The stock market by the way was off 250 points on Friday. They trade $97 and change this morning and the Michael Jackson movie did what Bernie?

MCGUIRK: $101 million in one week. Number one at the Box office over the weekend.

IMUS: And Jamie McMurray won the Talladega, Warner?

WOLF: Yes, he did. He had won the race in, I guess 85 tries. At least 85 years even.

IMUS: But they couldn't finish, I mean, but a couple of time -- they just -- they would go around a couple times and then they wreck.

WOLF: Oh, yes, Ryan Newman, he crashed with the -- 5 lapse to go.

(CROSSTALK)

IMUS: That was horrible. He was lucky to walk away with that one.

WOL: Yes. They had to caught him out of the car.

IMUS: I saw that. We should talk more about him or show some of that. It is a quarter after the hour here on the imus in the morning program.

Big Kenny is coming up and he is going to sing. This is from his record. The quiet time of a rock and roll farm boy.

(MUSIC PLAYING)

IMUS IN THE MORNING

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

IMUS: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Time now for a business update from the Fox Business Network. Here is Jenna Lee.

LEE: Good morning everybody. Here is your Fox Business minute. We had earnings news just breaking at the top of the hour from Humana. The health insurance earning a $1.78 as the penny better than the estimate. Revenue however was a little lighter than expectations, $7.7 billion. Also, the company's 2010 earnings guidance is lower than the current analyst forecast. Keep an eye on that stocks this morning.

Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs is trying to buy tax credits from Fannie Mae. According to the Wall Street Journal, a deal would provide much-needed cash to Fannie while saving Goldman millions of dollars on its taxes. But the treasury may block this deal because of potential backlash if Goldman which is already cashing hit for making billions gets a round paying some taxes.

If you have millions of dollars to blow on vacation, listen up, the first hotel in space should be ready for guests in just three years from now. $4.4 million gets you three nights at the Galactic Suite Space Resort. That price includes an 8 weeks training course on the Tropical Island as well. At least, 43 people have reportedly already reserved. That is your fox business minute. The best business television is now live on the web.

Foxbusiness.com/live morning edition. For all this morning's breakings earnings news, log on from your computer or streaming on your iPhone. Here's a quick look at futures as we head into Monday's session after a massy Friday. At least, from positive territory. Now, over to Charles for look at the news headlines.

MCCORD: And Jenna, couple of the top stories. Casualty count is rising now in this latest violence in Pakistan and explosion in Rawalpindi city close to Pakistan's capital, Islamabad. And they're now saying at least 30 people have been killed and added some 45 wounded. The explosion occurring near a bank and the hotel not far from the army's main headquarters.

Coastguard now says its search effort after a Thursday's middle collision between the u.s. coast guard aircraft and the Marine Corps helicopter in the pacific of California. They say it is now a recovery operation. Officials say the active search for survivors has been suspended. There were nine people aboard the air craft.

And independent health advisor is keeping an eye on flu vaccine safety starting today. Not really expecting problems with the shot but the government is taking extra steps to track the health of millions of Americans. The idea is to spot any problems quickly and explain false alarms if they occur. Those are some of the top stories on the imus in the morning program continues for you right here, right now on the Fox Business Network.

(MUSIC PLAYING)

IMUS: It's 22 after the hour here on the imus in the morning program on the radio all over the country and on the Fox Business Network. Brand new radio affiliate today. That means as of this morning we are on 6,319 -- who is banging the mike around? Is that you Bernie?

MCGUIRK: That was me. That was me. Yes.

IMUS: We are on 6,319 radio stations. The newest being WRWC 99.3 fm in Newburgh, Middletown, New York. News talk 99.3. Time for sports, Warner Wolf. Sports sponsored by American made Peerless Boilers, there new 96% purifier series that beats out your basement. Visit peerlessboilers.com. Good morning Warner.

WOLF: Good morning I-man. Game four the Yankees with three in the nine. All with two outs of Brad Lidge. RBI double by A-Rod, two run single by Posada beat the Phillies seven-four and lead three games to one.

IMUS: Warner.

WOLF: Not yet.

IMUS: It's the World Series, right.

WOLF: It was A-Rod on its winning hit.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ALEXANDER RODRIGUEZ, BASEBALL PLAYER: I had a feeling, I mean, Tec (ph) is such a great header and I had a feeling it was going to come down to me and I was really looking forward to that opportunity.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WOLF: In the 9 pinning (ph) with the shipped (ph) on for the Sherah Denon (ph) stole second and third on the same play when nobody covered third base. Hey, Charlie Manuel, what was up with that?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHARLIE MANUEL, PHILADELPHIA PHILLIES MANAGER: Got to be heads up. We got shipped on like head. Police was covering second base. And there was really some miscommunication there.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

IMUS: This guy should be changing tires from Newman's car.

MCCORD: And that's it.

IMUS: And that is it. Nothing else.

IMUS: Poor Charlie, I mean, Come on! Poor Charlie. And you told me at the beginning of this whole thing, Warner I would like to remind you, that they wouldn't make the same count of mistakes the Angels made. What happened?

MCCORD: What happened?

IMUS: What happened? That's what I want to know.

WOLF: You know, you picked on poor Charlie because full of records by the way. Survived the heart attack, quadruple bypass surgery and kidney cancer.

IMUS: Well, he shouldn't change tires, he should just wipe the windows.

(LAUGHTER)

WOLF: Oh man.

IMUS: Wipe out the headlights.

WOLF: Game five tonight Cliff Lee won the game one-eight, Brett one game two. Future game 40-year-old Brett Favre returned to green bay through four touchdown passes. The Vikings jumped up to 24-3 halftime lead and never trailed. Beat green bay's 38-26.

IMUS: The other kid playing OK by the ...

(CROSSTALK)

urn:contentItem:7X16-YHK1-2SP6-J1SW-00000-00Interview with Matt Taibbi; Top Business Headlines; Top News Headlines; Sports Update; Interview With Big Kenny; Interview With Alan;[1]2009-11-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:24ZLexisNexisInterview with Matt Taibbi; Top Business Headlines; Top News Headlines; Sports Update; Interview With Big Kenny; Interview With Alan[1]

DON IMUS, HOST: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Time now for a business update from the Fox Business Network. Here is Jenna Lee.

JENNA LEE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Good morning everybody. Hope you had a good weekend. Coming up on IMUS IN THE MORNING.

Country star Big Kenny from Big and Rich Fame will join Imus to talk about his new album, play a little music for us this Monday morning. We are looking forward to that. Let's get to your Fox Business minute.

CIT group filing for bankruptcy, that's the big news today. It's the fifth largest bankruptcy in U.S. history. The lender was not able to get its bondholders to agree to a debt for equity offer but according to the Wall Street Journal CIT does have support for a prepackaged bankruptcy plan including funding from billionaire investor Carl Icahn. That could allow CIT to emerge from bankruptcy by the end of this year.

A big weekend for bank failures as fed sees nine more banks, the most ever to be shed down one day since the financial crisis begin. The banks will reopen today as u.s. Bank branches after the company stepped in and aggress to assume their deposit. This brings the total of bank failures so far this year to 115.

And other banking news executives from the country's 28 largest banks are meeting with Federal Reserve officials today to discuss compensation as well as regulation. The fed is looking to take information from the meeting and get a look at the compensation trends and practices used by the companies.

We also have some breaking earnings news at this hour as well for Humana. It looks like Humana is out with the -- it's earning $1.78 which would beat expectations by a penny. As far as revenue, it looks like revenue is a little bit light, 7.72 which is below the expectation of 7.82. So, keep an eye and Humana today. That's your Fox Business minute.

When you log on this morning. Go download the new Fox Business app, it's the only app that notifies you when your stock hits the target price you want. That's very important and you can do this while you're watching the best business television on the web live, foxbusiness.come/live or online right now to be sure to check us out, foxbusiness.com.

Here's a quick look at European markets. See how they're shaping up this Monday morning. And a quick look at futures as we show you Oil and Gold. imus in the morning is up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

IMUS: Based on the interview that he did yesterday on his program Chris Christie -- if he doesn't get elected government in New Jersey, maybe there is something is wrong.

(CROSSTALK)

IMUS: Politics -- but -- like Corzine is just a slimy, sleazy, Goldman Sachs thief, and an arrogant idiot dirt bag. All of that. But why do we need to get into this name calling, Bernie?

CHARLES MCCORD, HOST: Well, don't hold back here I-man.

IMUS: Here's what I don't like about, when I got fired, you know, and when I was coming back to work, this moron -- I wasn't going to talk about this but I will. He had some statement about what he thought that I ought to have to do to come back to work. And here's what he have to do -- he ought to kiss my ass. How does that sound?

ANNOUNCER: Ladies and Gentlemen, imus in the morning.

IMUS: Third day to my mind Charles.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: I will go down in history. February 15, 2004, when the Yankees traded for A-Rod.

MCCORD: Right.

IMUS: And of course, May 8, 2009, when it came back from a hit a home run.

MCCORD: Just exploded.

IMUS: There was never a doubt in my mind at any point that going back to February 15th, 2004, at the Yankees for marching on their way to the 27th world championship.

BERNARD MCGUIRK, HOST: May I just add rocket propelled to their 27th.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: So, way to go A-Rod.

WARNER WOLF, WARNER SPORT'S HOST: The name of the law (ph).

IMUS: What's the matter Warner?

(ALL TALKING AT ONCE)

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: The fat boy will be on with Cavuto. The next governor of New Jersey, kind of interesting. Whether you like him or not, it's not a decent job, and even if he hasn't, he is not a creep. You know, he figured out a way to put together $16 billion.

MCCORD: Yes, he did.

IMUS: He said to Corzine that he is a moron. And we know Corzine is a creep. And then I was watching the best of Imus, euphemistically speaking of course, on Saturday morning on the Fox Business Network. And half the time when I'm talking to people, I'm checking my e-mail.

MCCORD: I know its ugly reading his e-mail.

IMUS: I mean, it's difficult to get me to listen anyway.

MCCORD: Yes, sure because that's a God damn thing.

IMUS: It is clear I am not listening to a word they are saying. I was talking to Laura Ingram when she was going out her notes word by word and that's people I like.

MCCORD: Stunning that you are able to hold up your end of the conversation.

IMUS: Anyway, coming up this morning, Big Kenny is here.

MCCORD: All right.

IMUS: And he's got his love everybody. And we will be playing that song and we don't love anybody. There is no one.

(LAUGHTER)

MCCORD: Not a knocked on .

IMUS: You know what is new CD Charles?

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: The quiet times of a rock and roll farm boy. Which you can actually plant this thing.

MCCORD: No, you can't.

IMUS: This is way over thinking. No, no, no, it's fine, yes.

MCCORD: Really?

IMUS: But first we want to find out if we can listen to it which I would think.

MCCORD: What happens when you plant it?

IMUS: I don't know.

MCGUIRK: You could smoke it afterward.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: Yes, it grows and you could smoke it, you know.

ROB BARTLETT, COMEDIAN HOST: Hey, man. This is really good.

IMUS: So happy birthday to Big Kenny. It was his birthday yesterday. And his son's name, I think, is not Ford. It is not Chevy. It is Lincoln.

MCCORD: Lincoln, OK.

IMUS: Or Jefferson. No, it's Lincoln. It is Lincoln's birthday today.

MCCORD: Great.

IMUS: So, we got him a little cake. And Cally (ph) said he's already up. He is cranky but, you know, it is 6:00 in the morning in New York.

MCCORD: Sure.

IMUS: Anyway, Jenna Lee is going to have some business news at CIT. A thing that I don't understand at all but who else is doing business stuff?

STAFF: It's Dagen.

IMUS: Dagen McDowell. She will have some information about this as well. Warner Wolf, it is not over, right Warner?

WOLF: No, it's not over. Cliff Lee will win tonight two to nothing. Phillies will shoot out the Yankees two to nothing. Game six in New York on Wednesday.

IMUS: Then it's over.

WOLF: Good day. No, I'm thinking to go seven.

IMUS: Are you down?

WOLF: Yes. This is hopefully at the Seven Game Series.

IMUS: All right.

WOLF: And Charlie Manuel, I mean, I can't understand, he will going to get second guess forever. I don't care about three day's arrest. Cliff Lee had to pitch last night when you are down two games to one.

IMUS: Now you are down three to one.

WOLF: And now, you're down three to one. He had to pitch last night.

IMUS: He's going to pitch tonight?

WOLF: Yes, but if he wins you're still down now three-two. He had to pitch in the fourth game if you trail tow games to one.

IMUS: Well, but he didn't do it.

WOLF: He didn't do it. No.

IMUS: He will going to pitch tonight?

WOLF: Yes, that's right Imus.

IMUS: OK. Let's have to move on.

WOLF: Oh, my God.

(LAUGHTER)

MCCORD: He didn't pitch last night so .

IMUS: He's going first.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: All right. Here's Charles with some news.

MCCORD: An explosion in Pakistan's Rawalpindi City today has killed 20 people at least and wounded more than a dozen and here is a reporter on the scene there.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

reporter (voice-over): A motorcycle ride -- themselves up in a military garrison area. He get detonated the motorcycle just outside a bank where most of the employees of the security services and other civilians had come to either withdraw their salaries or deposit their salary cheques.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCCORD: The explosion took place in the neighborhood not far from the army's main headquarters, Rawalpindi just a few miles away from the capital Islamabad. Suspected militants have now hit Pakistan's several times in recent weeks killing at all around 250 people. And apparent retaliation for the Pakistani army got offensive and the Taliban stronghold in the northwest.

Afghanistan Abdullah Abdullah pulling out of this week's runoff. Secretary of State Clinton says that Mr. Abdullah's announcement does not calling to question the legitimacy of the recent election which President Karzai want with less that 50% of the vote.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HILLARY CLINTON, SECRETARY OF STATE: When President Karzai accepted the second round without knowing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

IMUS: We don't have to be really insulted by that nonsense. What did the Billy (ph) say? I thought the whole thing was a scam and a shame.

MCCORD: And would be again.

IMUS: And would be again, he just .

MCCORD: If he was down in the polls too.

IMUS: Yes, he was.

MCGUIRK: He was reading the -- I got lady and upstate New York who would be humiliated again.

IMUS: Well, I don't know. You think that was it was?

MCGUIRK: Yes.

IMUS: Well, OK. Never mine them.

MCCORD: Abdullah pull out of the run of this weekend after .

IMUS: Oh, let's go back and see what the first -- not the first lady but the secretary had to say.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CLINTON: When President Karzai accepted the second round without knowing what the consequences and outcome would be, that bestowed legitimacy from that moment forward and Dr. Abdullah's decision does not anyway take away from that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

IMUS: That's a very good point.

MCCORD: Very astute.

(CROSSTALK)

IMUS: Congratulations. That's very wonderful secretary of state.

MCCORD: And President Obama's top advisers say he will make a decision, now, quote, "within weeks on whether to send more troops to Afghanistan. They say Obama is going through a rigorous decision-making process because he wants to make sure that we got the strategy right."

IMUS: It is12 minutes after the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Time for the Fox Business Network, business report. Here with us is Dagen McDowell. Good morning Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Good morning sir.

IMUS: How are you?

MCDOWELL: I am fantastic.

IMUS: So, CIT is what? There going bankrupt but -- it's critical, right?

MCDOWELL: All right. No but still a critical part. A lending in this country, it is a 100-year-old lender to small and medium-size businesses and it does this specialty lending and specialty financing in particular retail. So, there are literally hundreds of thousands of retailers and vendors. People have made everything from close to hats that use CIT. Here is what you need to do. The American taxpayer with this bankruptcy just lost $2.3 billion. That's what you need to know. The first lost related to those financial bail-outs last year.

IMUS: You know, I was talking to Bernie while you're talking, so I don't know what you said.

MCDOWELL: OK. You want me to repeat it?

IMUS: No. Do you know what she said Charles?

MCCORD: Yes. I do.

IMUS: What is she saying?

MCCORD: That this thing is the leading provider of financing to retailers and their vendors and Dagen said that the bottom line, we were losing $2.3 billion with this thing going down.

MCDOWELL: Bottom line, American taxpayers just lost $2.3 billion with this bankruptcy.

IMUS: How so?

MCDOWELL: And, because we put money, we the American taxpayer's part of the financial bail out put that money in the CIT last year with the bankruptcy filing the taxpayers lost and this is the first lost, recorded lost from those bail outs that, you know, 400 billion plus bail outs to the financial firm.

IMUS: So, you mean that, they don't have to pay us back?

MCDOWELL: They are not going to pay us back. Right. They do not have to.

IMUS: That was not good.

MCDOWELL: No, that's not good. By the way, you know what? Big Kenny's from my neck of the wood. He's from Virginia.

IMUS: That's great. It's too bad you can't come in the green room, you guys will love all the time.

MCCORD: Oh, that's true.

MCDOWELL: I'll try to stay away from the guest in the green room especially if I they had their make up on.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: No make on? You look fine.

MCDOWELL: OK.

IMUS: Have you come down with -- Van Morrison was there the whole day.

(LAUGHTER)

MCCORD: Another reason to stay away with guests in the green room.

IMUS: Yes, anyway, thanks Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Thank you sir.

IMUS: The stock market by the way was off 250 points on Friday. They trade $97 and change this morning and the Michael Jackson movie did what Bernie?

MCGUIRK: $101 million in one week. Number one at the Box office over the weekend.

IMUS: And Jamie McMurray won the Talladega, Warner?

WOLF: Yes, he did. He had won the race in, I guess 85 tries. At least 85 years even.

IMUS: But they couldn't finish, I mean, but a couple of time -- they just -- they would go around a couple times and then they wreck.

WOLF: Oh, yes, Ryan Newman, he crashed with the -- 5 lapse to go.

(CROSSTALK)

IMUS: That was horrible. He was lucky to walk away with that one.

WOL: Yes. They had to caught him out of the car.

IMUS: I saw that. We should talk more about him or show some of that. It is a quarter after the hour here on the imus in the morning program.

Big Kenny is coming up and he is going to sing. This is from his record. The quiet time of a rock and roll farm boy.

(MUSIC PLAYING)

IMUS IN THE MORNING

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

IMUS: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Time now for a business update from the Fox Business Network. Here is Jenna Lee.

LEE: Good morning everybody. Here is your Fox Business minute. We had earnings news just breaking at the top of the hour from Humana. The health insurance earning a $1.78 as the penny better than the estimate. Revenue however was a little lighter than expectations, $7.7 billion. Also, the company's 2010 earnings guidance is lower than the current analyst forecast. Keep an eye on that stocks this morning.

Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs is trying to buy tax credits from Fannie Mae. According to the Wall Street Journal, a deal would provide much-needed cash to Fannie while saving Goldman millions of dollars on its taxes. But the treasury may block this deal because of potential backlash if Goldman which is already cashing hit for making billions gets a round paying some taxes.

If you have millions of dollars to blow on vacation, listen up, the first hotel in space should be ready for guests in just three years from now. $4.4 million gets you three nights at the Galactic Suite Space Resort. That price includes an 8 weeks training course on the Tropical Island as well. At least, 43 people have reportedly already reserved. That is your fox business minute. The best business television is now live on the web.

Foxbusiness.com/live morning edition. For all this morning's breakings earnings news, log on from your computer or streaming on your iPhone. Here's a quick look at futures as we head into Monday's session after a massy Friday. At least, from positive territory. Now, over to Charles for look at the news headlines.

MCCORD: And Jenna, couple of the top stories. Casualty count is rising now in this latest violence in Pakistan and explosion in Rawalpindi city close to Pakistan's capital, Islamabad. And they're now saying at least 30 people have been killed and added some 45 wounded. The explosion occurring near a bank and the hotel not far from the army's main headquarters.

Coastguard now says its search effort after a Thursday's middle collision between the u.s. coast guard aircraft and the Marine Corps helicopter in the pacific of California. They say it is now a recovery operation. Officials say the active search for survivors has been suspended. There were nine people aboard the air craft.

And independent health advisor is keeping an eye on flu vaccine safety starting today. Not really expecting problems with the shot but the government is taking extra steps to track the health of millions of Americans. The idea is to spot any problems quickly and explain false alarms if they occur. Those are some of the top stories on the imus in the morning program continues for you right here, right now on the Fox Business Network.

(MUSIC PLAYING)

IMUS: It's 22 after the hour here on the imus in the morning program on the radio all over the country and on the Fox Business Network. Brand new radio affiliate today. That means as of this morning we are on 6,319 -- who is banging the mike around? Is that you Bernie?

MCGUIRK: That was me. That was me. Yes.

IMUS: We are on 6,319 radio stations. The newest being WRWC 99.3 fm in Newburgh, Middletown, New York. News talk 99.3. Time for sports, Warner Wolf. Sports sponsored by American made Peerless Boilers, there new 96% purifier series that beats out your basement. Visit peerlessboilers.com. Good morning Warner.

WOLF: Good morning I-man. Game four the Yankees with three in the nine. All with two outs of Brad Lidge. RBI double by A-Rod, two run single by Posada beat the Phillies seven-four and lead three games to one.

IMUS: Warner.

WOLF: Not yet.

IMUS: It's the World Series, right.

WOLF: It was A-Rod on its winning hit.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ALEXANDER RODRIGUEZ, BASEBALL PLAYER: I had a feeling, I mean, Tec (ph) is such a great header and I had a feeling it was going to come down to me and I was really looking forward to that opportunity.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WOLF: In the 9 pinning (ph) with the shipped (ph) on for the Sherah Denon (ph) stole second and third on the same play when nobody covered third base. Hey, Charlie Manuel, what was up with that?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHARLIE MANUEL, PHILADELPHIA PHILLIES MANAGER: Got to be heads up. We got shipped on like head. Police was covering second base. And there was really some miscommunication there.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

IMUS: This guy should be changing tires from Newman's car.

MCCORD: And that's it.

IMUS: And that is it. Nothing else.

IMUS: Poor Charlie, I mean, Come on! Poor Charlie. And you told me at the beginning of this whole thing, Warner I would like to remind you, that they wouldn't make the same count of mistakes the Angels made. What happened?

MCCORD: What happened?

IMUS: What happened? That's what I want to know.

WOLF: You know, you picked on poor Charlie because full of records by the way. Survived the heart attack, quadruple bypass surgery and kidney cancer.

IMUS: Well, he shouldn't change tires, he should just wipe the windows.

(LAUGHTER)

WOLF: Oh man.

IMUS: Wipe out the headlights.

WOLF: Game five tonight Cliff Lee won the game one-eight, Brett one game two. Future game 40-year-old Brett Favre returned to green bay through four touchdown passes. The Vikings jumped up to 24-3 halftime lead and never trailed. Beat green bay's 38-26.

IMUS: The other kid playing OK by the ...

(CROSSTALK)

WOLF: No offensive line, sacked six times. Most of the fans booed Favre of. It was Farve after the game.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIPE)

BRETT FARVE, MINNESOTA VIKINGS: I mean, there was some purple. I sought a mixture of everything. Cheers, fingers.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

IMUS: He started crying somebody told me.

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: You can't play football and cry.

WOLF: No, it's no crying in football.

IMUS: He got to stop crying. Tennis players crying. You can cry. Andre Agassi -- this is really weird.

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: He played in the French open in 1990. Remember all that long hair he had?

WOLF: Yes. That was hot.

IMUS: It turns out it was a rug. And he claims he lost the French open because -- this is not funny. Because he was worried that his hair piece was going to fall off.

WOLF: That's right. That is a distraction, sure.

IMUS: How great would that have been known. He stood out on that dirt and played at the French open. All right. Big Kenny wants to sing. All right. Wrap this up.

WOLF: All right. Well and we know that Meb Keflezighi becomes the first u.s., The actually U.S. citizen to win the marathon in 27 years.

There you go. And Jimmy Johnson finished six to Talladega but he now leads Mark Martin by 184 points which just three races to go.

IMUS: Well, they go to Texas this week and Phoenix and down the homestretch and it is over.

WOLF: It's over.

IMUS: Twenty six after the hour on the imus in the morning program. All right. Please welcome to the imus in the morning program Big Kenny. His album is called, the quiet times of a rock and roll farm boy. He's got one wake up.

(MUSIC PLAYING)

DON IMUS, FBN ANCHOR: All right, we're back. Thanks, Kenny. Thirty minutes after the hour and also coming up this morning Matt Taibbi from Rolling Stone and we'll talk to Bo Dietl. McKenny will be back in "Imus in the Morning."

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

IMUS: This is "Imus in the Morning" program, time now for a business update. From the FOX Business Network, here is Jenna Lee.

JENNA LEE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK: Good Monday morning everybody. Let's get straight to your Fox Business Minute.

Bank of America's list of candidates to replace CEO, Ken Lewis is looking even shorter after another prospect reportedly told the bank no thanks. The Wall Street Journal says () approached Bank of New York CEO, Robert Kelly. Kelly has been approached before about succeeding Ken Lewis, but is showing no interest in the job.

Bernie Madoff's auditor is expected to plead guilty. Prosecutor say David Frieling reached a deal with the government and will enter his plea tomorrow. In the meantime, in a Jailhouse interview, Madoff telling the Security and Exchange Commission, he considers current SEC chair, Mary Schapiro, "Dear friend and that she, quote, probably thinks I wish I never knew this guy." He also went on to say that he was, "very proud of the role he played in the industry."

Ford releasing a third quarter results shortly. The US automaker is expected to continue to crawl back towards the black. Analysts expect Ford to report a loss of $0.12 a share revenue as expected to come in at just over $2 billion. We will bring you those numbers, of course, as they break. That's your "Fox Business Minute." The best business television is now live on the web, foxbusiness.com live morning edition. () this morning breaking () log on from your computer or streaming on your iPhone. Here is a quick look at futures. You are watching "Imus in the Morning" on Fox Business.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The basic healthcare is a right of every American should have.

IMUS: I agree with that but this was all public option thing --.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Right.

IMUS: What I'm saying that just - well, it doesn't work in these other countries and they ought to be pulling the plug on grandma.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: That is just ridiculous. The plug is already being pulled because insurance companies have death penalty. That's already happening.

IMUS: Wouldn't you agree that there comes a point where you've got to say to grandma look. You know, she is sitting there and the corn () is dripping out of her mouth --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I say, so now you flipped and you say death panels are good.

IMUS: She is staring at the TV and the TV is not on, and you're thinking well -

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It maybe time.

IMUS: That maybe enough.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I want Imus on my death panel.

IMUS: I am sorry, I didn't have better questions, Juan (ph). I apologize and I am sorry I was rude to you and adversarial. I didn't mean it.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I love it when you grovel.

IMUS: It is 36 minutes past the hour here on the "Imus in the Morning" program on the radio all over the country and on the Fox Business Network. I didn't mention the new radio affiliate today, WRWC 99.3 FM on Newburg, Middletown, New York. News Talk 99.3, good to have them aboard. That's brings the list now to 6,319 radio stations, Charles.

CHARLES: Pretty good.

IMUS: Well, Bo Dietl's appearance sponsored by Netjets and we're always happy to have Bo here. Netjets 1-877-netjets or go to netjets.com. Good morning, Mr. Dietl.

BO DIETL: Good morning, Don. One more day to go, you know, it's just funny after we had -

IMUS: Why are you shaking hands with Kenny, do you know him?

DIETL: I've met him before, yes I did and -

IMUS: They were good, aren't they?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REX RYAN, JETS COACH: You know, we're at 500 and the only way to get out is we've got to come out with our hair on fire.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WOLF: Oh, well that will do it.

The Colts stayed unbeaten. Beat the 49ers 18-14. Fourth-quarter touchdown pass from Joseph Addai. No relation to Joseph Abud (ph). Stephane Marberry (ph) showed up . . .

IMUS: Oh, stop. You're about to get suspended.

MCCORD: Oh, man.

WOLF: Stephane Marberry showed up at the Knicks home opener Saturday night, I-man.

IMUS: Do you drink wine before we start or during.

WOLF: No, after.

IMUS: Oh, OK.

WOLF: He stood up taking video tape of the game, blocking the view of fans behind him. When ushers asked for Marberry's ticket, he was in the wrong row. He was asked to move, but instead he left when they asked him for his bag.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: (INAUDIBLE).

(END VIDEO CLIP)

IMUS: Oh, no, that's it. You're suspended. Get it.

Twenty-five after the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Please welcome to the program now Big Kenny.

Good morning, Big Kenny.

BIG ALPHIN: Thank you, Don. Very good to be here.

IMUS: Happy birthday.

ALPHIN: Thank you, thank you, thank you. And happy birthday to my little one. Yes, Lincoln.

IMUS: Little Lincoln is four years old there, right?

ALPHIN: Yes, Lincoln's four years old.

IMUS: We got him a cake. It has instructions (ph).

ALPHIN: Awesome. Awesome. Good. And everything's going to be great. He loves the celebration.

IMUS: Oh, he does.

ALPHIN: He's a celebrating kid.

IMUS: What does he think? Does he tell you what he thinks when he watches you sing?

ALPHIN: Yes. Yes.

IMUS: What does he think?

ALPHIN: He likes it. He likes it.

IMUS: He does?

ALPHIN: He loves being around the instruments and he loves singing and playing music and he's always dressing up like some character. I mean he knows he's Captain America. He knows he's Captain America and he's a rock star. He knows that right now, yes.

IMUS: So how do you like being out here on your own?

ALPHIN: I love -- oh, I'm having a blast, man. I love it all. You know, I love the -- having -- being able to play music in every fashion that I have with John and Big & Rich and with all my other friends that I've made music with over the years. I just -- I love what I do. I'm excited now that we're doing -- that I'm doing something different. It lets me speak of where I'm at in my life right now.

You know, I was a bust (ph) just like Lord knows everybody else here in the early '90s when that first crippling recession came through and I had 75 employees and a construction business. And within three months, every bank that was around went out of business, was taken over by the Comptroller of the Currency, and that was when the savings and loan scandal came through.

And then I was trying to build my way out of it. I was always singing or humming around on a job site. A buddy comes up one day and says, hey, Kenny, you sing pretty good. You ought to go to Nashville. You know they pay people to write songs down there. And I set my framing hammer down and I look at him and I said, you've got to be kidding. I've been farming and slamming nails all this time and, you know, just, you know, hard work. Making hay. You know, it's hard work.

And, you know what, over the past 15 years, since I've moved to Nashville, I've found out that song writing is hard work too. Meaning, you have to put a lot of time into it to do something great.

IMUS: Yes.

ALPHIN: But now I've not only gotten to a point where I've had some success in music, but I've got a family, I've got a son. As of this past year, we were able -- me and my wife work with a group called My Sister's Keeper and have a -- got a school built over the past three years right in the middle of Sudan. Got 550 young girls registered in there, having their first chance at education 45 kilometers outside of a war zone. We've got doctors, we're giving away scholarships in the Appellation now because the water's so blooming contaminated and all this area that I call home, you know, we've got to let people know that the water can be killing their kids, like lead paint was back in the '70s, you know.

IMUS: Please don't turn into my wife.

ALPHIN: Well, I'm not. But -- and the way to do that is to plant -- have music that's gross.

IMUS: How does this work? We're talking with Big Kenny here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. The album's called "The Quite Times of a Rock and Roll Farm Boy." How does this -- how do you plant this? I mean it's an unusual packaging.

ALPHIN: Well, my -- yes. We had to come up with that.

IMUS: Remember, a lot of the people are listening to the radio.

ALPHIN: Yes, we had to come up with that packaging. Instead of using a plastic jewel case, which I just got tired of seeing them stacked around everywhere.

IMUS: Sure.

ALPHIN: You know, I figure, what, there's hundreds of millions of records made every week. If we could just get rid of those one plastic jewel cases, that could be a pile as big as the Empire State Building. Huge. So we made a package that just -- it's a cardboard folder that folds up and you can put your CD, take it out or put it back in or you can take the package and it's plantable. Meaning we put in the cardboard 26 different varieties of my favorite perennial wildflower seeds. So you can just wet the stuff and break it up into pieces and put it in flower pot and plant it or you could just throw it out in your backyard and it's biodegradable, it's compostable. It will just wither to nothing. So worst thing is, if these -- if there are packages everywhere, our way will be paved in flowers.

IMUS: What's this business about loving everybody, because we don't love anybody.

ALPHIN: Oh, I don't believe that for a minute.

IMUS: Well, we don't love everybody.

(LAUGHTER)

ALPHIN: Well -- and it just struck me like a lightning bolt. I guess, you know, having gone through a business bust and a lot of other things in my life, and having the time as a writer to spend time a lot of time thinking and writing my thoughts down in all these crazy songs -- and this album of songs that I've written now, it really does describe my life -- I just decided that that was the best way to look at everything, every question that I had, all the things that were consuming my mind that I saw as issues throughout the world, or things that were right around me, with people that were just around me. I said the best thing I can do is just follow one rule, and that's, well, I just love everybody, no matter what.

IMUS: Yes.

ALPHIN: I know it's not the easiest thing in the world, but it can be done.

IMUS: You have a white aura around you.

ALPHIN: A white aura?

IMUS: Yes.

MCCORD: That's positive. That's good.

IMUS: That's good.

MCCORD: That is good.

IMUS: Let me ask you a question you have never been asked.

ALPHIN: OK.

IMUS: Are you and John going to record again?

ALPHIN: I hope so, yes. I would think so.

We've put a lot of energy into building what we've built so far. John is getting ready to be a daddy, I understand, and so a lot of things are changing in his world right now.

I had to hang upside down last year like a bat. I was trying to get my neck fixed naturally, without having to do what my daddy had been telling me all my life, and that was, "Son, sooner or later, you're going to have to get your head screwed on straight." So this doctor in Nashville finally went in after this injury I sustained in 2002 from being hit by a drunk driver. He went into my throat and my spine.

He screwed a metal plate. So I am now bionic Big Kenny.

IMUS: Well, when John was here, he told us you were doing that. I just assumed that he was lying and that you all couldn't get along.

ALPHIN: No.

IMUS: Because look at Brooks & Dunn after all these years. Well, Ronnie Dunn finally figured out -- it took him 20 years -- that he is the only one who could sing in that group. So -- I mean, the other guy is fine, but...

(LAUGHTER)

ALPHIN: Well, I think it's -- as musicians, it's good for us. John wanted to express a lot of songs that I wouldn't -- that wouldn't naturally come from me. And these songs that make up all of Big Kenny, "The Quiet Times of a Rock and Roll Farm Boy," these are the songs of my life right now.

IMUS: Well, you all toured this summer, didn't you?

ALPHIN: Yes, we toured this summer and did all the Big and Rich classics. And then he played a couple, I played a couple. We had a blast. We did most of the country this summer.

IMUS: Well, people like you individually. They love -- and they may wind up loving both of you individually.

ALPHIN: Yes, I would hope so. They call me the Jack White of country music, or the...

IMUS: Jack White?

ALPHIN: Yes. He's recorded with Loretta Lynn.

IMUS: I love Jack White.

ALPHIN: He's recorded with...

IMUS: Well, that record he made with Loretta Lynn was great. That was a great record.

ALPHIN: Yes. I want to make more records just -- I've got a studio built in my back yard now. It didn't necessarily start out like that.

It started out because I was working so much, touring so much. And we were -- we tried to move across the street because we could park the bus off the street and make our neighbors happier. And then my wife's going to work, and "All the time you're building the house, you're not going to church enough, honey."

So, to solve that, I had a friend come over. We sketched up a nice little building that looked kind of like a church, and we started building that in the back yard. And then my buddies are coming back going, "Wow, this would make a great studio."

So now every time at home I've solved all the issues. I'm right there for my kid. He'd come running in just like I could run into the shop when my dad was working on the farm.

I've got music in a studio around me all the time so I can get quiet, think and write. And, hey, I'm in church too.

IMUS: Praise the lord. Praise Jesus.

Big Kenny is going to sing for us in just a little bit here.

ALPHIN: Amen.

IMUS: It's 33 after the hour.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

IMUS: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program.

Time now for our business update from the Fox Business Network.

Here's Jenna Lee.

LEE: Good morning, everybody. Here's your "Fox Business Minute."

Bank of America's list of candidates to replace CEO Ken Lewis is looking even shorter after another prospect reportedly told the bank no thanks. "The Wall Street Journal" says Bank of America approached Bank of New York Mellon CEO Robert Kelly. Kelly has been approached before for succeeding Ken Lewis, but is showing no interest in the job as of yet.

Bernie Madoff's auditors expected to plead guilty. Prosecutors say David Friehling reached a deal with the government and will enter his plea tomorrow.

In the meantime, in a jailhouse interview, Bernie Madoff telling the Securities and Exchange Commission he considers current SEC chair Mary Schapiro "a dear friend," and that she "... probably thinks I wish I never knew this guy."

Moving on to a different story here, winter came early in Beijing. The city waking up to snow on Sunday, to the earliest snowfall in 10 years.

Meteorologists seated (ph) clouds with silver iodide, forcing the snow to fall. Beijing's city offices said because it's suffering from a drought, it won't miss an opportunity for artificial precipitation.

There's a look at it. It looks like a lot of snow.

Quick earnings news for you. Clorox saying H1N1, the flu, actually helping out sales. They had a big beat here. Adjusted earnings, $1.18, versus the expectation of 95 cents. Revenue right in line with expectations, $1.37 billion.

That's your "Fox Business Minute."

If you're on the move this morning or at a computer, check us out for all the latest business headlines -- FoxBusiness.com/livemorningedition, streaming on your iPhone and online.

Here's a quick look at the futures. We have more IMUS IN THE MORNING coming up.

MCCORD: The House plan includes a government-run public run option and is expected to cost less than $900 billion over 10 years. House Republican Mike Pence of Indiana, though, fears it goes way too far and calls it, in fact, a freight train.

IMUS: I mean, at some point, don't you have to say to grandma, look, that's enough?

MCCORD: No. What are you talking about?

MCGUIRK: Well, maybe, but coming from the government is a little...

MCCORD: Why would you say that to grandma under any circumstances?

IMUS: Well, grandma is sitting there with the food falling out of her mouth, staring at the TV, and the TV is not on.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: I mean...

MCCORD: That's just great.

IMUS: Well, I'm just saying.

MCCORD: So you slip over behind grandma...

MCGUIRK: Be careful what you wish for.

IMUS: You can tell he's a sweet guy.

MCCORD: Oh, he's a lovely man.

IMUS: He just looks at me and he says, "Why do you hate everybody?" I said no, it's a joke. We don't hate everybody, we just hate you.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: No, we don't hate anybody. Well, we hate -- do we hate -- no, we don't hate anybody. We just don't love everybody.

All right. Well, an album you can plant, that's reason enough to buy it, "The Quiet Times of a Rock and Roll Farm Boy."

Once again, please welcome Big Kenny.

(MUSIC)

IMUS: Oh, man, that's a great song. That's a great song.

Big Kenny, he'll be back with one more.

It's 17 until the hour.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

IMUS: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program.

Time now for a business update from the Fox Business Network.

Here's Connell McShane.

MCSHANE: Hi. Good morning to you.

And coming up just moments from now on "THE OPENING BELL," I will be in for Alexis, and I'll be joined by a couple of former senators -- Bob Graham and Jim Talent. They're on different sides of the aisle, but both men agree that investing in vaccines is important to the nation's security. We're talking H1N1.

We'll find out why on "THE OPENING BELL."

All right. Let's get to your "Fox Business Minute" now, with AIG dropping its plans to sell some Japanese units.

According to "The Wall Street Journal," AIG is going to keep two of the three life insurance units initially it had tried to sell. Now, this fits with the plan set forward by the CEO, Robert Benmosche, when he took over back in August. AIG, by the way, still owes the government some $85 billion.

The liquidation of Lehman Brothers continues with a sale of more than $1 million worth of art. The 283 lots brought in a total of $1.35 million, nearly twice the expectations. Now, the artwork once hung on the walls of Lehman's corporate offices here in New York, and the money hardly puts a dent on the $250 billion that Lehman still owes its creditors.

Now, the big news this morning from Ford, For Motor Company reporting third quarter earnings results that blew past analysts' estimates. They reported a profit of 26 cents a share, $30.9 billion in revenue, when they were expected to have lost money.

Ford says its turnaround plan is on track for the time frame they've targeted. You see the stock. It's higher in pre-market trading.

That is your "Fox Business Minute."

Speaking of higher, let's take a look at the futures this morning. They are also pointing to the possibility of a higher open on Wall Street.

We'll be covering it all on "THE OPENING BELL," which is coming up at the top of the hour. I will be in for Alexis on that.

More IMUS IN THE MORNING right now on Fox Business.

IMUS: Eleven minutes until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program, on the radio all the country and on the Fox Business Network.

I just got an e-mail from the ayatollah, Charles.

MCCORD: What's this one? God Almighty.

IMUS: Well, that would be Mrs. Imus.

MCCORD: Yes, boy. What does she want?

IMUS: She says, regarding Big Kenny, "What a great guy he is. His glasses look like yours."

OK.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: "We should be planting every CD cover. When we buy plastic CD covers," according to my wife, who is to the right of Sean Hannity, she says, "the terrorists win."

Well, all right.

Neil Cavuto will have the fat boy on tonight, our guy, Chris Christie. And -- now I'm not sure they will be in the same studio. I'm not sure that that's possible, actually.

(LAUGHTER)

MCGUIRK: That ain't right.

IMUS: They'll be a two-shot, those two boys.

MCGUIRK: You got your wide screen.

IMUS: Yes.

Coming up next hour, Matt Taibbi from "Rolling Stone."

Tomorrow, Mike Lupica. His new book, "Million-Dollar Throw," Wyatt Imus read and loved. And, of course, Lupica has written four or five of them, "The New York Times" number one bestsellers.

And then on Wednesday, Jeff Greenfield from CBS and Monica Crowley from way out there where the buses don't run. So that kind of situation.

All right, time for one more here. You all please welcome once again, singing something from -- that last song, that was a great song. This is from -- oh, how about this one, Imus? Maybe this would be great, too -- "The Quite Times of a Rock and Roll Farm Boy," Big Kenny.

(MUSIC)

IMUS: Big Kenny.

ALPHIN: Thank you.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

IMUS: Please welcome to the IMUS IN THE MORNING program from Fox News, actually, and his own syndicated national radio program that is doing splendid, our old friend Alan Colmes.

Good morning, Mr. Colmes.

ALAN COLMES, RADIO TALK SHOW HOST: Hello, Mr. Imus.

IMUS: Well, how about all the stuff President Obama promised he was going to do and he's done none of it? None of it.

COLMES: The guy's been in office a few minutes.

IMUS: None of it. He's been in office almost a year. He has done nof it.

COLMES: OK. That justifies Lieberman.

IMUS: He has done none of it.

COLMES: He's getting out of Iraq in 22 months.

IMUS: He was the agent of change. He's not going to get out of Iraq in anything.

COLMES: Sure he is.

IMUS: How about "Don't Ask, Don't Tell?" How about Guantanamo?

COLMES: I'd like to see him move faster on some things. He inherited a nightmare from the previous administration.

IMUS: Oh, well, you can't spend the rest of your life blaming that incompetent buffoon who was the president before this guy.

COLMES: You've got to sweep up the mess that was left.

IMUS: Well, yes, but grab a mop and get busy then, as he said.

COLMES: What do you think he's doing? He was just praised for going to Dover Air Force Base. That's change you can believe.

IMUS: That's one thing he did that was good.

MCCORD: Symbolic.

IMUS: I like the guy, by the way. I mean, Sean Hannity, it makes him insane when I say that, but I do like him. But I don't think he has any idea what he's doing, and he's more interested in being president...

COLMES: Oh, that's just ridiculous.

IMUS: ... spending five hours playing golf with that dope Tom Friedman.

COLMES: I'm with O'Reilly on this one. The guy's not allowed to have a golf game?

IMUS: No, not to...

COLMES: The guy can't go enjoy himself for a few hours?

IMUS: No, no, not to -- no, come on. Do you have five hours to go play -- you probably do, but I don't have five hours to go do anything.

COLMES: Wait a minute. So, when George W. Bush said, "I'm playing through" after he was talking about the tragedy of 9/11, that was OK, right?

IMUS: Well, I didn't say it was OK.

(CROSSTALK)

IMUS: I didn't vote for him. I didn't vote for him either time. What are you talking about?

COLMES: Well, I'm just pointing out to your audience the hypocrisy there.

IMUS: Pardon me?

COLMES: I'm pointing out the hypocrisy in the situation.

IMUS: Well, it's completely lost on me, and now you've irritated me. So...

COLMES: Oh, I'm really sorry.

IMUS: No you're not. You don't care at all.

COLMES: I don't know how I can make it up to you.

IMUS: You don't care about me.

COLMES: Yes, I do.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

IMUS: Tonight at 6:00 p.m. Eastern Time on the Fox Business Network, Neil Cavuto will interview our new favorite fat boy, New Jersey gubernatorial candidate Chris Christie.

And speaking of -- well, not fat boys, but Cavuto -- but then we could make a case for -- well, whatever. He'll be on this program tomorrow morning, along with Mike Lupica. He'll be talking about his new book, "Million- Dollar Throw."

Right now, time for "THE OPENING BELL."

END

urn:contentItem:5JB6-1GX1-DY0W-409R-00000-00Interview with Matt Taibbi; Top Business Headlines; Top News Headlines; Sports Update; Interview With Big Kenny; Interview With Alan;[1]2009-11-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:24ZLexisNexisInterview with Matt Taibbi; Top Business Headlines; Top News Headlines; Sports Update; Interview With Big Kenny; Interview With Alan[1]LanhamFULL TEXT

DON IMUS, HOST: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Time now for a business update from the Fox Business Network. Here is Jenna Lee.

JENNA LEE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Good morning everybody. Hope you had a good weekend. Coming up on IMUS IN THE MORNING.

Country star Big Kenny from Big and Rich Fame will join Imus to talk about his new album, play a little music for us this Monday morning. We are looking forward to that. Let's get to your Fox Business minute.

CIT group filing for bankruptcy, that's the big news today. It's the fifth largest bankruptcy in U.S. history. The lender was not able to get its bondholders to agree to a debt for equity offer but according to the Wall Street Journal CIT does have support for a prepackaged bankruptcy plan including funding from billionaire investor Carl Icahn.
