So you can just wet the stuff and break it up into pieces and put it in flower pot and plant it or you could just throw it out in your backyard and it's biodegradable, it's compostable. It will just wither to nothing. So worst thing is, if these -- if there are packages everywhere, our way will be paved in flowers.

IMUS: What's this business about loving everybody, because we don't love anybody.

ALPHIN: Oh, I don't believe that for a minute.

IMUS: Well, we don't love everybody.

(LAUGHTER)

ALPHIN: Well -- and it just struck me like a lightning bolt. I guess, you know, having gone through a business bust and a lot of other things in my life, and having the time as a writer to spend time a lot of time thinking and writing my thoughts down in all these crazy songs -- and this album of songs that I've written now, it really does describe my life -- I just decided that that was the best way to look at everything, every question that I had, all the things that were consuming my mind that I saw as issues throughout the world, or things that were right around me, with people that were just around me. I said the best thing I can do is just follow one rule, and that's, well, I just love everybody, no matter what.

IMUS: Yes.

ALPHIN: I know it's not the easiest thing in the world, but it can be done.

IMUS: You have a white aura around you.

ALPHIN: A white aura?

IMUS: Yes.

MCCORD: That's positive. That's good.

IMUS: That's good.

MCCORD: That is good.

IMUS: Let me ask you a question you have never been asked.

ALPHIN: OK.

IMUS: Are you and John going to record again?

ALPHIN: I hope so, yes. I would think so.

We've put a lot of energy into building what we've built so far. John is getting ready to be a daddy, I understand, and so a lot of things are changing in his world right now.

I had to hang upside down last year like a bat. I was trying to get my neck fixed naturally, without having to do what my daddy had been telling me all my life, and that was, "Son, sooner or later, you're going to have to get your head screwed on straight." So this doctor in Nashville finally went in after this injury I sustained in 2002 from being hit by a drunk driver. He went into my throat and my spine.

He screwed a metal plate. So I am now bionic Big Kenny.

IMUS: Well, when John was here, he told us you were doing that. I just assumed that he was lying and that you all couldn't get along.

ALPHIN: No.

IMUS: Because look at Brooks & Dunn after all these years. Well, Ronnie Dunn finally figured out -- it took him 20 years -- that he is the only one who could sing in that group. So -- I mean, the other guy is fine, but...

(LAUGHTER)

ALPHIN: Well, I think it's -- as musicians, it's good for us. John wanted to express a lot of songs that I wouldn't -- that wouldn't naturally come from me. And these songs that make up all of Big Kenny, "The Quiet Times of a Rock and Roll Farm Boy," these are the songs of my life right now.

IMUS: Well, you all toured this summer, didn't you?

ALPHIN: Yes, we toured this summer and did all the Big and Rich classics. And then he played a couple, I played a couple. We had a blast. We did most of the country this summer.

IMUS: Well, people like you individually. They love -- and they may wind up loving both of you individually.

ALPHIN: Yes, I would hope so. They call me the Jack White of country music, or the...

IMUS: Jack White?

ALPHIN: Yes. He's recorded with Loretta Lynn.

IMUS: I love Jack White.

ALPHIN: He's recorded with...

IMUS: Well, that record he made with Loretta Lynn was great. That was a great record.

ALPHIN: Yes. I want to make more records just -- I've got a studio built in my back yard now. It didn't necessarily start out like that.

It started out because I was working so much, touring so much. And we were -- we tried to move across the street because we could park the bus off the street and make our neighbors happier. And then my wife's going to work, and "All the time you're building the house, you're not going to church enough, honey."

So, to solve that, I had a friend come over. We sketched up a nice little building that looked kind of like a church, and we started building that in the back yard. And then my buddies are coming back going, "Wow, this would make a great studio."

So now every time at home I've solved all the issues. I'm right there for my kid. He'd come running in just like I could run into the shop when my dad was working on the farm.

I've got music in a studio around me all the time so I can get quiet, think and write. And, hey, I'm in church too.

IMUS: Praise the lord. Praise Jesus.

Big Kenny is going to sing for us in just a little bit here.

ALPHIN: Amen.

IMUS: It's 33 after the hour.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

IMUS: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program.

Time now for our business update from the Fox Business Network.

Here's Jenna Lee.

LEE: Good morning, everybody. Here's your "Fox Business Minute."

Bank of America's list of candidates to replace CEO Ken Lewis is looking even shorter after another prospect reportedly told the bank no thanks. "The Wall Street Journal" says Bank of America approached Bank of New York Mellon CEO Robert Kelly. Kelly has been approached before for succeeding Ken Lewis, but is showing no interest in the job as of yet.

Bernie Madoff's auditors expected to plead guilty. Prosecutors say David Friehling reached a deal with the government and will enter his plea tomorrow.

In the meantime, in a jailhouse interview, Bernie Madoff telling the Securities and Exchange Commission he considers current SEC chair Mary Schapiro "a dear friend," and that she "... probably thinks I wish I never knew this guy."

Moving on to a different story here, winter came early in Beijing. The city waking up to snow on Sunday, to the earliest snowfall in 10 years.

Meteorologists seated (ph) clouds with silver iodide, forcing the snow to fall. Beijing's city offices said because it's suffering from a drought, it won't miss an opportunity for artificial precipitation.

There's a look at it. It looks like a lot of snow.

Quick earnings news for you. Clorox saying H1N1, the flu, actually helping out sales. They had a big beat here. Adjusted earnings, $1.18, versus the expectation of 95 cents. Revenue right in line with expectations, $1.37 billion.

That's your "Fox Business Minute."

If you're on the move this morning or at a computer, check us out for all the latest business headlines -- FoxBusiness.com/livemorningedition, streaming on your iPhone and online.

Here's a quick look at the futures. We have more IMUS IN THE MORNING coming up.

MCCORD: The House plan includes a government-run public run option and is expected to cost less than $900 billion over 10 years. House Republican Mike Pence of Indiana, though, fears it goes way too far and calls it, in fact, a freight train.

IMUS: I mean, at some point, don't you have to say to grandma, look, that's enough?

MCCORD: No. What are you talking about?

MCGUIRK: Well, maybe, but coming from the government is a little...

MCCORD: Why would you say that to grandma under any circumstances?

IMUS: Well, grandma is sitting there with the food falling out of her mouth, staring at the TV, and the TV is not on.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: I mean...

MCCORD: That's just great.

IMUS: Well, I'm just saying.

MCCORD: So you slip over behind grandma...

MCGUIRK: Be careful what you wish for.

IMUS: You can tell he's a sweet guy.

MCCORD: Oh, he's a lovely man.

IMUS: He just looks at me and he says, "Why do you hate everybody?" I said no, it's a joke. We don't hate everybody, we just hate you.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: No, we don't hate anybody. Well, we hate -- do we hate -- no, we don't hate anybody. We just don't love everybody.

All right. Well, an album you can plant, that's reason enough to buy it, "The Quiet Times of a Rock and Roll Farm Boy."

Once again, please welcome Big Kenny.

(MUSIC)

IMUS: Oh, man, that's a great song. That's a great song.

Big Kenny, he'll be back with one more.

It's 17 until the hour.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

IMUS: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program.

Time now for a business update from the Fox Business Network.

Here's Connell McShane.

MCSHANE: Hi. Good morning to you.

And coming up just moments from now on "THE OPENING BELL," I will be in for Alexis, and I'll be joined by a couple of former senators -- Bob Graham and Jim Talent. They're on different sides of the aisle, but both men agree that investing in vaccines is important to the nation's security. We're talking H1N1.

We'll find out why on "THE OPENING BELL."

All right. Let's get to your "Fox Business Minute" now, with AIG dropping its plans to sell some Japanese units.

According to "The Wall Street Journal," AIG is going to keep two of the three life insurance units initially it had tried to sell. Now, this fits with the plan set forward by the CEO, Robert Benmosche, when he took over back in August. AIG, by the way, still owes the government some $85 billion.

The liquidation of Lehman Brothers continues with a sale of more than $1 million worth of art. The 283 lots brought in a total of $1.35 million, nearly twice the expectations. Now, the artwork once hung on the walls of Lehman's corporate offices here in New York, and the money hardly puts a dent on the $250 billion that Lehman still owes its creditors.

Now, the big news this morning from Ford, For Motor Company reporting third quarter earnings results that blew past analysts' estimates. They reported a profit of 26 cents a share, $30.9 billion in revenue, when they were expected to have lost money.

Ford says its turnaround plan is on track for the time frame they've targeted. You see the stock. It's higher in pre-market trading.

That is your "Fox Business Minute."

Speaking of higher, let's take a look at the futures this morning. They are also pointing to the possibility of a higher open on Wall Street.

We'll be covering it all on "THE OPENING BELL," which is coming up at the top of the hour. I will be in for Alexis on that.

More IMUS IN THE MORNING right now on Fox Business.

IMUS: Eleven minutes until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program, on the radio all the country and on the Fox Business Network.

I just got an e-mail from the ayatollah, Charles.

MCCORD: What's this one? God Almighty.

IMUS: Well, that would be Mrs. Imus.

MCCORD: Yes, boy. What does she want?

IMUS: She says, regarding Big Kenny, "What a great guy he is. His glasses look like yours."

OK.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: "We should be planting every CD cover. When we buy plastic CD covers," according to my wife, who is to the right of Sean Hannity, she says, "the terrorists win."

Well, all right.

Neil Cavuto will have the fat boy on tonight, our guy, Chris Christie. And -- now I'm not sure they will be in the same studio. I'm not sure that that's possible, actually.

(LAUGHTER)

MCGUIRK: That ain't right.

IMUS: They'll be a two-shot, those two boys.

MCGUIRK: You got your wide screen.

IMUS: Yes.

Coming up next hour, Matt Taibbi from "Rolling Stone."

Tomorrow, Mike Lupica. His new book, "Million-Dollar Throw," Wyatt Imus read and loved. And, of course, Lupica has written four or five of them, "The New York Times" number one bestsellers.

And then on Wednesday, Jeff Greenfield from CBS and Monica Crowley from way out there where the buses don't run. So that kind of situation.

All right, time for one more here. You all please welcome once again, singing something from -- that last song, that was a great song. This is from -- oh, how about this one, Imus? Maybe this would be great, too -- "The Quite Times of a Rock and Roll Farm Boy," Big Kenny.

(MUSIC)

IMUS: Big Kenny.

ALPHIN: Thank you.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

IMUS: Please welcome to the IMUS IN THE MORNING program from Fox News, actually, and his own syndicated national radio program that is doing splendid, our old friend Alan Colmes.

Good morning, Mr. Colmes.

ALAN COLMES, RADIO TALK SHOW HOST: Hello, Mr. Imus.

IMUS: Well, how about all the stuff President Obama promised he was going to do and he's done none of it? None of it.

COLMES: The guy's been in office a few minutes.

IMUS: None of it. He's been in office almost a year. He has done nof it.

COLMES: OK. That justifies Lieberman.

IMUS: He has done none of it.

COLMES: He's getting out of Iraq in 22 months.

IMUS: He was the agent of change. He's not going to get out of Iraq in anything.

COLMES: Sure he is.

IMUS: How about "Don't Ask, Don't Tell?" How about Guantanamo?

COLMES: I'd like to see him move faster on some things. He inherited a nightmare from the previous administration.

IMUS: Oh, well, you can't spend the rest of your life blaming that incompetent buffoon who was the president before this guy.

COLMES: You've got to sweep up the mess that was left.

IMUS: Well, yes, but grab a mop and get busy then, as he said.

COLMES: What do you think he's doing? He was just praised for going to Dover Air Force Base. That's change you can believe.

IMUS: That's one thing he did that was good.

MCCORD: Symbolic.

IMUS: I like the guy, by the way. I mean, Sean Hannity, it makes him insane when I say that, but I do like him. But I don't think he has any idea what he's doing, and he's more interested in being president...

COLMES: Oh, that's just ridiculous.

IMUS: ... spending five hours playing golf with that dope Tom Friedman.

COLMES: I'm with O'Reilly on this one. The guy's not allowed to have a golf game?

IMUS: No, not to...

COLMES: The guy can't go enjoy himself for a few hours?

IMUS: No, no, not to -- no, come on. Do you have five hours to go play -- you probably do, but I don't have five hours to go do anything.

COLMES: Wait a minute. So, when George W. Bush said, "I'm playing through" after he was talking about the tragedy of 9/11, that was OK, right?

IMUS: Well, I didn't say it was OK.

(CROSSTALK)

IMUS: I didn't vote for him. I didn't vote for him either time. What are you talking about?

COLMES: Well, I'm just pointing out to your audience the hypocrisy there.

IMUS: Pardon me?

COLMES: I'm pointing out the hypocrisy in the situation.

IMUS: Well, it's completely lost on me, and now you've irritated me. So...

COLMES: Oh, I'm really sorry.

IMUS: No you're not. You don't care at all.

COLMES: I don't know how I can make it up to you.

IMUS: You don't care about me.

COLMES: Yes, I do.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

IMUS: Tonight at 6:00 p.m. Eastern Time on the Fox Business Network, Neil Cavuto will interview our new favorite fat boy, New Jersey gubernatorial candidate Chris Christie.

And speaking of -- well, not fat boys, but Cavuto -- but then we could make a case for -- well, whatever. He'll be on this program tomorrow morning, along with Mike Lupica. He'll be talking about his new book, "Million- Dollar Throw."

Right now, time for "THE OPENING BELL."

END

So it looks like a beat for earnings per share. A little bit miss or a little bit ...

urn:contentItem:51D0-69P1-JB30-V14R-00000-00Interview with Matt Taibbi; Top Business Headlines; Top News Headlines; Sports Update; Interview With Big Kenny; Interview With Alan Colmes, Blast in Pakistan's Rawalpindi City Kills Twenty People2009-11-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:24ZLexisNexisIMUS IN THE MORNING6:00 AM ESTBo Deitl, Matt Taibbi,: William Kenneth Alphin, Alan ColmesNEWSInternational110201cb.220Interview with Matt Taibbi; Top Business Headlines; Top News Headlines; Sports Update; Interview With Big Kenny; Interview With Alan Colmes, Blast in Pakistan's Rawalpindi City Kills Twenty PeopleDon Imus, Jenna Lee, Charles McCord, Bernie McGuirk, Connell McShane, Lou Rufino, Warner Wolf, Dagen McDowell

DON IMUS, HOST: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Time now for a business update from the Fox Business Network. Here is Jenna Lee.

JENNA LEE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Good morning everybody. Hope you had a good weekend. Coming up on IMUS IN THE MORNING.

Country star Big Kenny from Big and Rich Fame will join Imus to talk about his new album, play a little music for us this Monday morning. We are looking forward to that. Let's get to your Fox Business minute.

CIT group filing for bankruptcy, that's the big news today. It's the fifth largest bankruptcy in U.S. history. The lender was not able to get its bondholders to agree to a debt for equity offer but according to the Wall Street Journal CIT does have support for a prepackaged bankruptcy plan including funding from billionaire investor Carl Icahn. That could allow CIT to emerge from bankruptcy by the end of this year.

A big weekend for bank failures as fed sees nine more banks, the most ever to be shed down one day since the financial crisis begin. The banks will reopen today as u.s. Bank branches after the company stepped in and aggress to assume their deposit. This brings the total of bank failures so far this year to 115.

And other banking news executives from the country's 28 largest banks are meeting with Federal Reserve officials today to discuss compensation as well as regulation. The fed is looking to take information from the meeting and get a look at the compensation trends and practices used by the companies.

We also have some breaking earnings news at this hour as well for Humana. It looks like Humana is out with the -- it's earning $1.78 which would beat expectations by a penny. As far as revenue, it looks like revenue is a little bit light, 7.72 which is below the expectation of 7.82. So, keep an eye and Humana today. That's your Fox Business minute.

When you log on this morning. Go download the new Fox Business app, it's the only app that notifies you when your stock hits the target price you want. That's very important and you can do this while you're watching the best business television on the web live, foxbusiness.come/live or online right now to be sure to check us out, foxbusiness.com.

Here's a quick look at European markets. See how they're shaping up this Monday morning. And a quick look at futures as we show you Oil and Gold. imus in the morning is up next.

IMUS: Based on the interview that he did yesterday on his program Chris Christie -- if he doesn't get elected government in New Jersey, maybe there is something is wrong.

(CROSSTALK)

IMUS: Politics -- but -- like Corzine is just a slimy, sleazy, Goldman Sachs thief, and an arrogant idiot dirt bag. All of that. But why do we need to get into this name calling, Bernie?

CHARLES MCCORD, HOST: Well, don't hold back here I-man.

IMUS: Here's what I don't like about, when I got fired, you know, and when I was coming back to work, this moron -- I wasn't going to talk about this but I will. He had some statement about what he thought that I ought to have to do to come back to work. And here's what he have to do -- he ought to kiss my ass. How does that sound?

ANNOUNCER: Ladies and Gentlemen, imus in the morning.

IMUS: Third day to my mind Charles.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: I will go down in history. February 15, 2004, when the Yankees traded for A-Rod.

MCCORD: Right.

IMUS: And of course, May 8, 2009, when it came back from a hit a home run.

MCCORD: Just exploded.

IMUS: There was never a doubt in my mind at any point that going back to February 15th, 2004, at the Yankees for marching on their way to the 27th world championship.

BERNARD MCGUIRK, HOST: May I just add rocket propelled to their 27th.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: So, way to go A-Rod.

WARNER WOLF, WARNER SPORT'S HOST: The name of the law (ph).

IMUS: What's the matter Warner?

(ALL TALKING AT ONCE)

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: The fat boy will be on with Cavuto. The next governor of New Jersey, kind of interesting. Whether you like him or not, it's not a decent job, and even if he hasn't, he is not a creep. You know, he figured out a way to put together $16 billion.

MCCORD: Yes, he did.

IMUS: He said to Corzine that he is a moron. And we know Corzine is a creep. And then I was watching the best of Imus, euphemistically speaking of course, on Saturday morning on the Fox Business Network. And half the time when I'm talking to people, I'm checking my e-mail.

MCCORD: I know its ugly reading his e-mail.

IMUS: I mean, it's difficult to get me to listen anyway.

MCCORD: Yes, sure because that's a God damn thing.

IMUS: It is clear I am not listening to a word they are saying. I was talking to Laura Ingram when she was going out her notes word by word and that's people I like.

MCCORD: Stunning that you are able to hold up your end of the conversation.

IMUS: Anyway, coming up this morning, Big Kenny is here.

MCCORD: All right.

IMUS: And he's got his love everybody. And we will be playing that song and we don't love anybody. There is no one.

(LAUGHTER)

MCCORD: Not a knocked on .

IMUS: You know what is new CD Charles?

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: The quiet times of a rock and roll farm boy. Which you can actually plant this thing.

MCCORD: No, you can't.

IMUS: This is way over thinking. No, no, no, it's fine, yes.

MCCORD: Really?

Bernie Madoff's auditors expected to plead guilty. Prosecutors say David Friehling reached a deal with the government and will enter his plea tomorrow.

In the meantime, in a jailhouse interview, Bernie Madoff telling the Securities and Exchange Commission he considers current SEC chair Mary Schapiro "a dear friend," and that she "... probably thinks I wish I never knew this guy."

Moving on to a different story here, winter came early in Beijing. The city waking up to snow on Sunday, to the earliest snowfall in 10 years.

Meteorologists seated (ph) clouds with silver iodide, forcing the snow to fall. Beijing's city offices said because it's suffering from a drought, it won't miss an opportunity for artificial precipitation.

There's a look at it. It looks like a lot of snow.

Quick earnings news for you. Clorox saying H1N1, the flu, actually helping out sales. They had a big beat here. Adjusted earnings, $1.18, versus the expectation of 95 cents. Revenue right in line with expectations, $1.37 billion.

That's your "Fox Business Minute."

If you're on the move this morning or at a computer, check us out for all the latest business headlines -- FoxBusiness.com/livemorningedition, streaming on your iPhone and online.

Here's a quick look at the futures. We have more IMUS IN THE MORNING coming up.

MCCORD: The House plan includes a government-run public run option and is expected to cost less than $900 billion over 10 years. House Republican Mike Pence of Indiana, though, fears it goes way too far and calls it, in fact, a freight train.

IMUS: I mean, at some point, don't you have to say to grandma, look, that's enough?

MCCORD: No. What are you talking about?

MCGUIRK: Well, maybe, but coming from the government is a little...

MCCORD: Why would you say that to grandma under any circumstances?

IMUS: Well, grandma is sitting there with the food falling out of her mouth, staring at the TV, and the TV is not on.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: I mean...

MCCORD: That's just great.

IMUS: Well, I'm just saying.

MCCORD: So you slip over behind grandma...

MCGUIRK: Be careful what you wish for.

IMUS: You can tell he's a sweet guy.

MCCORD: Oh, he's a lovely man.

IMUS: He just looks at me and he says, "Why do you hate everybody?" I said no, it's a joke. We don't hate everybody, we just hate you.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: No, we don't hate anybody. Well, we hate -- do we hate -- no, we don't hate anybody. We just don't love everybody.

All right. Well, an album you can plant, that's reason enough to buy it, "The Quiet Times of a Rock and Roll Farm Boy."

Once again, please welcome Big Kenny.

(MUSIC)

IMUS: Oh, man, that's a great song. That's a great song.

Big Kenny, he'll be back with one more.

It's 17 until the hour.

IMUS: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program.

Time now for a business update from the Fox Business Network.

Here's Connell McShane.

MCSHANE: Hi. Good morning to you.

And coming up just moments from now on "THE OPENING BELL," I will be in for Alexis, and I'll be joined by a couple of former senators -- Bob Graham and Jim Talent. They're on different sides of the aisle, but both men agree that investing in vaccines is important to the nation's security. We're talking H1N1.

We'll find out why on "THE OPENING BELL."

All right. Let's get to your "Fox Business Minute" now, with AIG dropping its plans to sell some Japanese units.

According to "The Wall Street Journal," AIG is going to keep two of the three life insurance units initially it had tried to sell. Now, this fits with the plan set forward by the CEO, Robert Benmosche, when he took over back in August. AIG, by the way, still owes the government some $85 billion.

The liquidation of Lehman Brothers continues with a sale of more than $1 million worth of art. The 283 lots brought in a total of $1.35 million, nearly twice the expectations. Now, the artwork once hung on the walls of Lehman's corporate offices here in New York, and the money hardly puts a dent on the $250 billion that Lehman still owes its creditors.

Now, the big news this morning from Ford, For Motor Company reporting third quarter earnings results that blew past analysts' estimates. They reported a profit of 26 cents a share, $30.9 billion in revenue, when they were expected to have lost money.

Ford says its turnaround plan is on track for the time frame they've targeted. You see the stock. It's higher in pre-market trading.

That is your "Fox Business Minute."

Speaking of higher, let's take a look at the futures this morning. They are also pointing to the possibility of a higher open on Wall Street.

We'll be covering it all on "THE OPENING BELL," which is coming up at the top of the hour. I will be in for Alexis on that.

More IMUS IN THE MORNING right now on Fox Business.

IMUS: Eleven minutes until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program, on the radio all the country and on the Fox Business Network.

I just got an e-mail from the ayatollah, Charles.

MCCORD: What's this one? God Almighty.

IMUS: Well, that would be Mrs. Imus.

MCCORD: Yes, boy. What does she want?

IMUS: She says, regarding Big Kenny, "What a great guy he is. His glasses look like yours."

OK.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: "We should be planting every CD cover. When we buy plastic CD covers," according to my wife, who is to the right of Sean Hannity, she says, "the terrorists win."

Well, all right.

Neil Cavuto will have the fat boy on tonight, our guy, Chris Christie. And -- now I'm not sure they will be in the same studio. I'm not sure that that's possible, actually.

(LAUGHTER)

MCGUIRK: That ain't right.

IMUS: They'll be a two-shot, those two boys.

MCGUIRK: You got your wide screen.

IMUS: Yes.

Coming up next hour, Matt Taibbi from "Rolling Stone."

Tomorrow, Mike Lupica. His new book, "Million-Dollar Throw," Wyatt Imus read and loved. And, of course, Lupica has written four or five of them, "The New York Times" number one bestsellers.

And then on Wednesday, Jeff Greenfield from CBS and Monica Crowley from way out there where the buses don't run. So that kind of situation.

All right, time for one more here. You all please welcome once again, singing something from -- that last song, that was a great song. This is from -- oh, how about this one, Imus? Maybe this would be great, too -- "The Quite Times of a Rock and Roll Farm Boy," Big Kenny.

(MUSIC)

IMUS: Big Kenny.

ALPHIN: Thank you.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

IMUS: Please welcome to the IMUS IN THE MORNING program from Fox News, actually, and his own syndicated national radio program that is doing splendid, our old friend Alan Colmes.

Good morning, Mr. Colmes.

ALAN COLMES, RADIO TALK SHOW HOST: Hello, Mr. Imus.

IMUS: Well, how about all the stuff President Obama promised he was going to do and he's done none of it? None of it.

COLMES: The guy's been in office a few minutes.

IMUS: None of it. He's been in office almost a year. He has done nof it.

COLMES: OK. That justifies Lieberman.

IMUS: He has done none of it.

COLMES: He's getting out of Iraq in 22 months.

IMUS: He was the agent of change. He's not going to get out of Iraq in anything.

COLMES: Sure he is.

IMUS: How about "Don't Ask, Don't Tell?" How about Guantanamo?

COLMES: I'd like to see him move faster on some things. He inherited a nightmare from the previous administration.

IMUS: Oh, well, you can't spend the rest of your life blaming that incompetent buffoon who was the president before this guy.

COLMES: You've got to sweep up the mess that was left.

IMUS: Well, yes, but grab a mop and get busy then, as he said.

COLMES: What do you think he's doing? He was just praised for going to Dover Air Force Base. That's change you can believe.

IMUS: That's one thing he did that was good.

MCCORD: Symbolic.

IMUS: I like the guy, by the way. I mean, Sean Hannity, it makes him insane when I say that, but I do like him. But I don't think he has any idea what he's doing, and he's more interested in being president...

COLMES: Oh, that's just ridiculous.

IMUS: ... spending five hours playing golf with that dope Tom Friedman.

COLMES: I'm with O'Reilly on this one. The guy's not allowed to have a golf game?

IMUS: No, not to...

COLMES: The guy can't go enjoy himself for a few hours?

IMUS: No, no, not to -- no, come on. Do you have five hours to go play -- you probably do, but I don't have five hours to go do anything.

COLMES: Wait a minute. So, when George W. Bush said, "I'm playing through" after he was talking about the tragedy of 9/11, that was OK, right?

IMUS: Well, I didn't say it was OK.

(CROSSTALK)

IMUS: I didn't vote for him. I didn't vote for him either time. What are you talking about?

COLMES: Well, I'm just pointing out to your audience the hypocrisy there.

IMUS: Pardon me?

COLMES: I'm pointing out the hypocrisy in the situation.

IMUS: Well, it's completely lost on me, and now you've irritated me. So...

COLMES: Oh, I'm really sorry.

IMUS: No you're not. You don't care at all.

COLMES: I don't know how I can make it up to you.

IMUS: You don't care about me.

COLMES: Yes, I do.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

IMUS: Tonight at 6:00 p.m. Eastern Time on the Fox Business Network, Neil Cavuto will interview our new favorite fat boy, New Jersey gubernatorial candidate Chris Christie.

And speaking of -- well, not fat boys, but Cavuto -- but then we could make a case for -- well, whatever. He'll be on this program tomorrow morning, along with Mike Lupica. He'll be talking about his new book, "Million- Dollar Throw."

Right now, time for "THE OPENING BELL."

urn:contentItem:5TNY-F7H1-F03R-N2VX-00000-00Interview with Max Tkachenko, the CEO of iTrue2018-11-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:23ZLexisNexisInterview with Max Tkachenko, the CEO of iTrueAngela Scott-Briggs

Nov 06, 2018( TechBullion: http://www.techbullion.com Delivered by Newstex) iTrue[1] is giving users control of their own data back from big tech firms. Also, business and individual users can earn rewards for participating in the data economy and decentralized app marketplace. The CEOMax Tkachenko will be telling us more about the iTrue project in this interview. 1) Please tell us your name and about yourself?

I'm Max Tkachenko. I was born in Russia, although I have been living in Miami, Flordia, in the US, for the last 15 years. I studied at Broward College in FL, and Computer Science at Harvard. After graduating, I opened my own business in the Cyber Forensics sector. I still have my own business involving in Cyber Forensics and Investigations, which services global clients. In my experience in developing security applications for clients in the financial sector and digital payment industries, I saw the need to detect and prevent fraud by use of biometric identities, which led me and my team to start iTrue. Prior to iTrue, I founded Genico, a digital security, AI and blockchain development company offering services to enterprises around the world. I have worked with over 280 projects with $107 million in total market capitalization. 2) What is iTrue and what services are you providing to the blockchain market? iTrue is a Blockchain based solution focused on giving users control of their own data back from big technology firms. On the front end, we secure access to the system with facial recognition software, which means your face (we call it 'Face Pass') is the key to your data. On the back end, all data is stored in a state-of-the-art Stone Storage solution, which is a combination of blockchain and distributed database technology. In addition, we offer an incentive system for users on our platform. Business and individual users can earn rewards for participating in the data economy and decentralized app marketplace. iTrue is therefore an innovative platform for storage and biometric identity for the decentralized web. It's not just a blockchain but a merge of blockchain and database. Although blockchain is immutable and data cannot be altered, our unique storage technology actually allows users to delete data upon request - which makes it compliant with GDPR and other existing data privacy rules. And nobody can read that deleted data as it is encrypted. Moreover, the iTrue system actually destroys the link to such deleted data. What remains is the record of deletion itself which is stored on our blockchain-based Stone Storage solution. [embedded content] 3)How does the ITrue ecosystem work and what is the technology behind the project? At the core of iTrue's platform is blockchain, which is the optimal way of storing data online in the future. We are tackling data security issues head on with our state-of-the-art Stone Storage solution, a distributed database that enables users to store information without the need for a centralized server, as it's based off of blockchain distributed ledger principles. With our Stone Storage solution, personal information is stored separately from its record of transaction and can be divided into different levels and categories. This allows users to decide which information to share with which party, putting users in complete control over sensitive information. We are taking data security to the next level by securing information using biometric technology. This means users must successfully verify their identity by scanning their face, eye iris, or other facial feature in order to access their stored data. The iTrue token economy primarily consists of a marketplace for data and a marketplace for decentralized applications. We have 2 models of data monetization: contact data (to get new clients) and UX data (for research purpose and insights how users interact with a product).In the contact data marketplace, participants can benefit as follows: Contractors, or entiites that collect and process data, can earn tokens or get new user data they don't have when they insert user data they have into the platform; Clients, or businesses that require user data, can acquire data by paying in tokens; Users earn token rewards when they share their personal contact data with contractors or clients.It should be noted that all requests for user data will require user approval, and they can also remove their personal data from the system, making iTrue fully compliant with privacy regulations like the GDPR.In the US data marketplace, participants can benefit this way: Clients, developers, or businesses that need testing of their existing or new application or system, can acquire anonymous UX data reports, which will include mimic reactions, eyes movement, fingers interaction with mouse and touch screen during testing of a product, by paying in tokens; Users earn token rewards when they participate in testing and share their UX data in anonymous view with clients.Meanwhile, in the decentralized app marketplace, participants can benefit as follows:Developers can build apps that take advantage of the existing modules (i.e., ID verification, Biometric recognition, Personal information, etc.). They can earn tokens when users or businesses use their turnkey solutions or require customized applications. Devs can also build and share their own modules; Enterprises can utilize either turnkey solutions or request their own customized applications; Individual users can either use tokens to pay for access to unique paid apps and get rewards when they use paid or free apps.4)What is the demand and market size of Blockchain-as-a-Service solutions and what unique benefit is iTrue bringing to this market? iTrue wants to bring together Blockchain technology and Biometric Identity standards in order to get rid of online fraud. Both industries are growth markets on their own, and we believe addressing both BaaS and Biometrics will enable us to make these technologies more accessible to both enterprises and users. The market for BaaS is estimated at US$ 623 million this year, which is set to grow to US$ 15.455 billion in five years. Demand for such services is distributed across industries, but the biggest demand will come from the banking, finance, and insurance industries. In terms of biometrics, smartphone manufacturers like Apple and Samsung have popularized their own versions of biometric authentication, such as fingerprint and face ID. While this pertains to the mass appeal of such technologies, there is a bigger potential, which is in commercial and enterprise usage. In terms of enterprise use, biometrics go beyond fingerprints. The global market for face ID was US$ 3.36 billion in 2016, and it will grow to US$6.84 billion by 2021. By 2022, it will shoot up to US$32.73 billion, according to Markets and Markets. It goes without saying that financial services will benefit greatly from the ability to make secure identification, authentication, and transactions through biometrics. Agricultural Bank of China is promoting withdrawals by facial recognition scans nationwide. Additionally, China Construction Bank has also announced commercial facial scan payments. Moreover, Shenzhen Metro, Tencent and GRG Banking jointly released a new solution which officially marked a new era of facial recognition - it will enable seamless and secure access to transport, communications, and frictionlness payments all through biometrics. Given that the growth in demand for BaaS will be supported by industries that relate to finance and fintech, it is only fitting that we also focus on the digital identity and security aspect. iTrue will make access to such financial and other services more convenient and secure through facial recognition. 5)Do you have any Competitors or similar use cases you will like to share with us? We can point out two main fields that we want to disrupt: BaaS and identity verification. In terms of BaaS, we can perhaps count blockchains that allow development of dApps as competitors, including NEO. Our main differentiator is that we have modular architecture, so we can add any new verified module. We can also support smart contracts written on any programming language, unlimited data capacity, and a robust search capability unmatched by any blockchain solution today. In terms of identity systems, there are a handful of blockchain platforms that have also launched with their own ID verification services, such as Civic and Verime. Here, again, we can highlight our integrated privacy controls, dApp development, and face verification as our main differentiators. 6) Please tell us more about the iTrue Token and token sale Conditions? We are currently on our private sale round. We accept investments from US$25,000 up, and we give 25% bonus during this round. 7) Do you have any major Partners or investors you will like to share with us, or any new opportunities for partners? Events and trade shows are one of the biggest use-cases of iTrue, and we are glad to have partnered with Trade Center Europa, one of the biggest chain of shopping and entertainment centers in Russia. We have partnered with Bancor Network, a decentralized liquidity network based in Zug, Switzerland which completed a historic Token Generation Event in June 2017. We're in negotiations with other e-commerce and offline business companies to launch pilot projects with help of our technologies. 8) On what stage of development is the ITrue platform, what is next on your Roadmap? We have developed our identity verification system, initially using facial recognition in user identification and verification. In terms of the technology, we have also accomplished our hybrid data storage solution, which is a combination of blockchain and database, thus ensuring ability to even run a search engine across the decentralized storage. We are currently working on an API to connect our platform and modules with third-party solutions. 9) Who are the experts behind this project, please tell us about your team and customer support? Our core team has had decades of experience in building secure and encrypted solutions for financial applications. In terms of blockchain and computer vision development, we have several experts on-board: Anton Gorozhankin, our CTO, has 15+ years experience in software architecture and product development, with expertise in payment gateways, billing systems, custom enterprise applications, and blockchain integration. Abhishek Gangwar is our Chief Computer Vision Engineer. With a decade experience in biometrics and computer vision technology, he has been associated with Aadhaar project and worked as a researcher in Computer Vision and Machine Learning domain at India's Centre for Development of Advanced Computing (C-DAC), which has around 15 branches all over India with more than 2,500 employees. Maxim Ankinin is our senior software developer. He has 10+ years experience in programming, creating solutions for variouscompanies from small utilities to big business systems, modelling for computer vision and other scientists' problem. He has worked with C/C++, Python 2/3 and various libraries (for example, OpenCV, ROOT, Boost, Qt 3/4/5 and others). He has experience with Linux (including low-level programming - writing Linux kernel modules), embedded systems (forexample, MIPS 64) and GPGPU solutions. A published technology author, Maxim has a PhD degree in computer vision (satellite imagery), artificial intelligence and machine learning. 10) How Safe is iTrue, would you like to talk about your legal and security measures? iTrue values user privacy, and thus we have built the platform with GDPR compliance at the outset. In terms of data storage, iTrue's Stone Storage solution utilizes a mix of blockchain transaction recording, along with encrypted database storage, to ensure a balance of security and performance. Encrypted personal data is stored in a decentralized network with controlled access. The system gets biometric data and additional metadata related to an operation in order to generate a crypto key. The data gets encoded by the generated public key, and finally it is transferred through protected interfaces. Confidential user data is never stored on personal devices for safety reasons, since personal devices are most likely to get hacked with the use of social engineering. 11) Do you have more information for our readers? Apart from our iTrue whitepaper, for quick reference, you can check out our investor deck here: https://itrue.io/files/iTrueInvestorDeck.pdf[2]. Recommended for you [ 1]:   https://itrue.io/ [ 2]:   https://itrue.io/files/iTrueInvestorDeck.pdf

urn:contentItem:5TNP-7JH1-JCMN-Y0PB-00000-00Interview with Max Tkachenko, the CEO of iTrue2018-11-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:23ZLexisNexisInterview with Max Tkachenko, the CEO of iTrueAngela Scott-Briggs

Nov 06, 2018( TechBullion: http://www.techbullion.com Delivered by Newstex) iTrue[1] is giving users control of their own data back from big tech firms. Also, business and individual users can earn rewards for participating in the data economy and decentralized app marketplace. The CEOMax Tkachenko will be telling us more about the iTrue project in this interview. 1) Please tell us your name and about yourself?

I'm Max Tkachenko. I was born in Russia, although I have been living in Miami, Flordia, in the US, for the last 15 years. I studied at Broward College in FL, and Computer Science at Harvard. After graduating, I opened my own business in the Cyber Forensics sector. I still have my own business involving in Cyber Forensics and Investigations, which services global clients. In my experience in developing security applications for clients in the financial sector and digital payment industries, I saw the need to detect and prevent fraud by use of biometric identities, which led me and my team to start iTrue. Prior to iTrue, I founded Genico, a digital security, AI and blockchain development company offering services to enterprises around the world. I have worked with over 280 projects with $107 million in total market capitalization. 2) What is iTrue and what services are you providing to the blockchain market? iTrue is a Blockchain based solution focused on giving users control of their own data back from big technology firms. On the front end, we secure access to the system with facial recognition software, which means your face (we call it 'Face Pass') is the key to your data. On the back end, all data is stored in a state-of-the-art Stone Storage solution, which is a combination of blockchain and distributed database technology. In addition, we offer an incentive system for users on our platform. Business and individual users can earn rewards for participating in the data economy and decentralized app marketplace. iTrue is therefore an innovative platform for storage and biometric identity for the decentralized web. It's not just a blockchain but a merge of blockchain and database. Although blockchain is immutable and data cannot be altered, our unique storage technology actually allows users to delete data upon request - which makes it compliant with GDPR and other existing data privacy rules. And nobody can read that deleted data as it is encrypted. Moreover, the iTrue system actually destroys the link to such deleted data. What remains is the record of deletion itself which is stored on our blockchain-based Stone Storage solution. [embedded content] 3)How does the ITrue ecosystem work and what is the technology behind the project? At the core of iTrue's platform is blockchain, which is the optimal way of storing data online in the future. We are tackling data security issues head on with our state-of-the-art Stone Storage solution, a distributed database that enables users to store information without the need for a centralized server, as it's based off of blockchain distributed ledger principles. With our Stone Storage solution, personal information is stored separately from its record of transaction and can be divided into different levels and categories. This allows users to decide which information to share with which party, putting users in complete control over sensitive information. We are taking data security to the next level by securing information using biometric technology. This means users must successfully verify their identity by scanning their face, eye iris, or other facial feature in order to access their stored data. The iTrue token economy primarily consists of a marketplace for data and a marketplace for decentralized applications. We have 2 models of data monetization: contact data (to get new clients) and UX data (for research purpose and insights how users interact with a product).In the contact data marketplace, participants can benefit as follows: Contractors, or entiites that collect and process data, can earn tokens or get new user data they don't have when they insert user data they have into the platform; Clients, or businesses that require user data, can acquire data by paying in tokens; Users earn token rewards when they share their personal contact data with contractors or clients.It should be noted that all requests for user data will require user approval, and they can also remove their personal data from the system, making iTrue fully compliant with privacy regulations like the GDPR.In the US data marketplace, participants can benefit this way: Clients, developers, or businesses that need testing of their existing or new application or system, can acquire anonymous UX data reports, which will include mimic reactions, eyes movement, fingers interaction with mouse and touch screen during testing of a product, by paying in tokens; Users earn token rewards when they participate in testing and share their UX data in anonymous view with clients.Meanwhile, in the decentralized app marketplace, participants can benefit as follows:Developers can build apps that take advantage of the existing modules (i.e., ID verification, Biometric recognition, Personal information, etc.). They can earn tokens when users or businesses use their turnkey solutions or require customized applications. Devs can also build and share their own modules; Enterprises can utilize either turnkey solutions or request their own customized applications; Individual users can either use tokens to pay for access to unique paid apps and get rewards when they use paid or free apps.4)What is the demand and market size of Blockchain-as-a-Service solutions and what unique benefit is iTrue bringing to this market? iTrue wants to bring together Blockchain technology and Biometric Identity standards in order to get rid of online fraud. Both industries are growth markets on their own, and we believe addressing both BaaS and Biometrics will enable us to make these technologies more accessible to both enterprises and users. The market for BaaS is estimated at US$ 623 million this year, which is set to grow to US$ 15.455 billion in five years. Demand for such services is distributed across industries, but the biggest demand will come from the banking, finance, and insurance industries. In terms of biometrics, smartphone manufacturers like Apple and Samsung have popularized their own versions of biometric authentication, such as fingerprint and face ID. While this pertains to the mass appeal of such technologies, there is a bigger potential, which is in commercial and enterprise usage. In terms of enterprise use, biometrics go beyond fingerprints. The global market for face ID was US$ 3.36 billion in 2016, and it will grow to US$6.84 billion by 2021. By 2022, it will shoot up to US$32.73 billion, according to Markets and Markets. It goes without saying that financial services will benefit greatly from the ability to make secure identification, authentication, and transactions through biometrics. Agricultural Bank of China is promoting withdrawals by facial recognition scans nationwide. Additionally, China Construction Bank has also announced commercial facial scan payments. Moreover, Shenzhen Metro, Tencent and GRG Banking jointly released a new solution which officially marked a new era of facial recognition - it will enable seamless and secure access to transport, communications, and frictionlness payments all through biometrics. Given that the growth in demand for BaaS will be supported by industries that relate to finance and fintech, it is only fitting that we also focus on the digital identity and security aspect. iTrue will make access to such financial and other services more convenient and secure through facial recognition. 5)Do you have any Competitors or similar use cases you will like to share with us? We can point out two main fields that we want to disrupt: BaaS and identity verification. In terms of BaaS, we can perhaps count blockchains that allow development of dApps as competitors, including NEO. Our main differentiator is that we have modular architecture, so we can add any new verified module. We can also support smart contracts written on any programming language, unlimited data capacity, and a robust search capability unmatched by any blockchain solution today. In terms of identity systems, there are a handful of blockchain platforms that have also launched with their own ID verification services, such as Civic and Verime. Here, again, we can highlight our integrated privacy controls, dApp development, and face verification as our main differentiators. 6) Please tell us more about the iTrue Token and token sale Conditions? We are currently on our private sale round. We accept investments from US$25,000 up, and we give 25% bonus during this round. 7) Do you have any major Partners or investors you will like to share with us, or any new opportunities for partners? Events and trade shows are one of the biggest use-cases of iTrue, and we are glad to have partnered with Trade Center Europa, one of the biggest chain of shopping and entertainment centers in Russia. We have partnered with Bancor Network, a decentralized liquidity network based in Zug, Switzerland which completed a historic Token Generation Event in June 2017. We're in negotiations with other e-commerce and offline business companies to launch pilot projects with help of our technologies. 8) On what stage of development is the ITrue platform, what is next on your Roadmap? We have developed our identity verification system, initially using facial recognition in user identification and verification. In terms of the technology, we have also accomplished our hybrid data storage solution, which is a combination of blockchain and database, thus ensuring ability to even run a search engine across the decentralized storage. We are currently working on an API to connect our platform and modules with third-party solutions. 9) Who are the experts behind this project, please tell us about your team and customer support? Our core team has had decades of experience in building secure and encrypted solutions for financial applications. In terms of blockchain and computer vision development, we have several experts on-board: Anton Gorozhankin, our CTO, has 15+ years experience in software architecture and product development, with expertise in payment gateways, billing systems, custom enterprise applications, and blockchain integration. Abhishek Gangwar is our Chief Computer Vision Engineer. With a decade experience in biometrics and computer vision technology, he has been associated with Aadhaar project and worked as a researcher in Computer Vision and Machine Learning domain at India's Centre for Development of Advanced Computing (C-DAC), which has around 15 branches all over India with more than 2,500 employees. Maxim Ankinin is our senior software developer. He has 10+ years experience in programming, creating solutions for various companies from small utilities to big business systems, modelling for computer vision and other scientists' problem. He has worked with C/C++, Python 2/3 and various libraries (for example, OpenCV, ROOT, Boost, Qt 3/4/5 and others). He has experience with Linux (including low-level programming - writing Linux kernel modules), embedded systems (for example, MIPS 64) and GPGPU solutions. A published technology author, Maxim has a PhD degree in computer vision (satellite imagery), artificial intelligence and machine learning. 10) How Safe is iTrue, would you like to talk about your legal and security measures? iTrue values user privacy, and thus we have built the platform with GDPR compliance at the outset. In terms of data storage, iTrue's Stone Storage solution utilizes a mix of blockchain transaction recording, along with encrypted database storage, to ensure a balance of security and performance. Encrypted personal data is stored in a decentralized network with controlled access. The system gets biometric data and additional metadata related to an operation in order to generate a crypto key. The data gets encoded by the generated public key, and finally it is transferred through protected interfaces. Confidential user data is never stored on personal devices for safety reasons, since personal devices are most likely to get hacked with the use of social engineering. 11) Do you have more information for our readers? Apart from our iTrue whitepaper, for quick reference, you can check out our investor deck here: https://itrue.io/files/iTrueInvestorDeck.pdf[2]. Recommended for you [ 1]:   https://itrue.io/ [ 2]:   https://itrue.io/files/iTrueInvestorDeck.pdf

There's been a lot of skepticism from <xhtml:span class="hit">regulators</xhtml:span> about Facebook getting into this cryptocurrency arena. Because think about it. ...</xhtml:span>

<xhtml:span id="h5" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... on this. Hadas Gold is here. So talk -- what has <xhtml:span class="hit">regulators</xhtml:span> concerned? What is the -- for anybody who hasn't shopped on ...</xhtml:span>

<xhtml:span id="h6" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... ZAPATA: The problem is not the technology, the problem is the <xhtml:span class="hit">regulations</xhtml:span> , first. How we can create enough safety and convince the ...</xhtml:span>

<xhtml:span id="h7" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... of sort of two main issues that the European Union competition <xhtml:span class="hit">regulator</xhtml:span> is looking into. Now, the buy box is something special that ...</xhtml:span>
