urn:contentItem:5VMD-VTC1-DY0W-41DW-00000-00Interview With Rep. Michael Turner (R) Ohio; Elizabeth Warren Unveils Plans to Break Up Giant Tech Firms; Interview With Mayor of Opelika, Alabama, Gary Fuller; Tornado Aftermath; Disappointing Jobs Report; House Republicans Question Cohen Testimony2019-03-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:24ZLexisNexisInterview With Rep. Michael Turner (R) Ohio; Elizabeth Warren Unveils Plans to Break Up Giant Tech Firms; Interview With Mayor of Opelika, Alabama, Gary Fuller; Tornado Aftermath; Disappointing Jobs Report; House Republicans Question Cohen TestimonyLanhamFULL TEXT

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOTBE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: The job market suffering, a big miss ahead of tomorrow's big 10-year bull anniversary.

From politics to pocketbooks, an incredible run-up. How did we get here? And what is ahead for your money?

Welcome, everyone. I'm Charles Payne in for Neil Cavuto. This is "Your World."

Those weaker-than-expected jobs numbers raising new concern about the economy, just as the bull market for the Dow and the S&P 500 turns 10 tomorrow. So, what does it mean for your money, the 2020 election? We are going to get to in a moment.

But, first, FOX team coverage with Susan Li with the action and John Roberts at the White House with the president's reaction, what he likes about today's report.

But we begin with Susan. She's outside the New York Stock Exchange -- Susan.

SUSAN LI, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Yes.

So, yes, we have the longest ever bull market run set to turn 10 on Saturday, forged from the destruction and the ashes of the global financial crisis. What a decade it's been.

Take a look at the performance of all the stock markets here in the U.S., the S&P and the Dow both up some 300 percent over those 10 years. The tech-heavy Nasdaq seeing gains of over 400 percent, thanks to the emergence of tech giants like Facebook, Netflix and Amazon during that period.

And it's not surprising that when we take a look at the best performing stocks over that 10-year period, Apple is at the top of the tree, up some 1300 percent. A surprising one in second place, Boeing, the plane maker, up some 1200 percent. UnitedHealth and Visa rounding out the top four.

Now, a bull market is defined as a sustained period of gains over 20 percent without a drop of 20 percent. We were very close to reaching those levels at the end of 2018. Close. Thank goodness we didn't get there. But today's jobs number, given that we saw a big miss, only 20,000 jobs in the month of February, 180,000 expected, this has investors concerned because bull markets usually don't last 10 years.

We are here in the final stages, according to a lot of investors, and these global growth concerns, whether it's slowing in China, Europe, people are concerned that it will come here to the U.S. at some point and end this bull market run that we're still in the middle of -- Charles.

PAYNE: Susan, thank you very, very much.

So, the question now is, who gets credit for this 10-year bull run, President Trump or former President Obama?

Let's ask our market pros.

Gary Kaltbaum is, Rebecca Walser and Scott Martin.

So, Gary, who gets the credit?

GARY KALTBAUM, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, under Obama, I give it to Obama and the central banks. Under Trump, I give Trump and the tax cuts and the regulatory cuts.

But I think the last two months, central banks are back in force not only here and around the globe, but, overall, I give the hard work and the ingenuity and the sweat and toil of the great American people and the great American companies that keep coming up with new inventions, new technologies, new medical breakthroughs. And I think the best is yet to come in the next 10 years.

PAYNE: Rebecca, when the market gets hammered the way it did right before President Obama came in, you do anticipate that it will rebound. And we were down 50 percent. It was ridiculously sold off.

But to the extent that it's rallied now, many people are really shocked that, 10 years later, we'd still be going like this.

REBECCA WALSER, WALSER WEALTH MANAGEMENT: Yes, absolutely, Charles.

But the thing is, I mean, let's be honest. Over Obama's full eight-year period, he had GDP at 1.5 percent. His last year in office, it was 1.6 percent and then Trump came in, in 2017 and took it to 2.3 percent. And that's what his economists had projected.

So, I give all the credit to President Trump, deregulatory policy, tax policy. And, unfortunately, I think Obama had higher wealth inequality and not real good job growth. So, GDP numbers were awful. So, no, it's unusual to have 10 years. This is the longest ever. And I do think the global slowdown is making investors nervous and it's interesting.

We're in a really interesting point.

PAYNE: You know, Scott, today, we did learn, also, what's interesting is that accompanying this rebound in the stock market is an economic recovery that's finally getting to the masses. Wages are up now big time, four months in a row over 3 percent. If you're a blue-collar worker, up seven months in a row over 3 percent.

We didn't think that could ever happen anymore. That goes part and parcel, of course, with this market, no?

SCOTT MARTIN, KINGSVIEW ASSET MANAGEMENT: Yes. And a couple of more job months or job growth months we are going to see, Charles, I think we're going to see in the next couple of months, we are going to see wages go towards 4 percent.

And you're seeing companies, too. You know, you guys talked about in kind of the previous comments about a little bit of different feel to the economy now, isn't it? It feels a little bit more self-sustaining. It feels a little more energetic vs., say, what it was in the previous administration.

So, you're seeing companies raise wages, minimum wage and things like that, because of the fact that they're confident about the regulatory environment going forward and they're confident about what's happening in D.C. now going forward.

So, that's another reason that companies, which is a good thing, are going to make their own decisions. They're going to breathe and live on their own and create job growth and create economic growth. And that, too, is going to keep this economy going in the coming years.

PAYNE: I want to go back to the New York Stock Exchange, bring Susan Li back into this.

What's interesting, Susan, is, overnight, China's stock market, their main market, the Shanghai, down more than 4 percent. It's been absolutely decimated over the last year, compared to our market, which is up significantly over the same time since President Trump has been in office.

LI: Yes.

PAYNE: As we head into the final phase of the China-U.S. trade talks, what kind of an impact does that give us? What kind of leverage does that give President Trump?

LI: Well, over the last 10 years, Charles, my favorite term has been the cleanest dirty shirts, and that's what the U.S. market and the U.S. economy has been.

And I would say actually especially true in the current environment in 2019. We do have a slowing economy taking place in China. They were down some 30 percent last year -- I would say probably the best performing stock market so far in 2019, but that all hinges on getting a U.S.-China trade deal.

Last night, we saw exports really falling off a cliff, down some 20 percent in a month. And don't forget, that is the bread and butter of the Chinese economy. That's what oils it. And if that's going down at this point, you can imagine that they are looking at a very sharp downturn and they want to sign a deal as soon as possible.

So maybe the U.S. and the Trump administration has the upper hand when it comes to signing possibly a trade truce.

PAYNE: Gary, you know, you brought up the Federal Reserve. Again, you know, Powell, let's give him credit for sinking the market in the fourth quarter of last year. Let's give him credit for maybe coming to his senses.

But now there's some concerns that the Fed is going to become even ultra-dovish and even trying to push this economy even further, and some people are concerned about that. So, where do you see interest rates?

KALTBAUM: Well, I was the first to say that they were going to stop dead in their tracks on raising rates. And I will be the first to say that the next move is going to be lowering of rates.

You know, look, we continue to be the very strong developing country. I don't -- I think China may be even in a recession. But we're not immune. I think we will slow down also. And I think Powell has already telegraphed it and I suspect we are going to see him lower rates during 2019, probably helps markets and, keep fingers crossed, keeps our economy in good stead.

And, again, let me repeat something. I give all the credit to Trump on not only lowering the taxes, but lowering the regulatory front. That was huge. Obama for eight years was the king of regulations and that needed to be undone. So good on this president.

PAYNE: There's no doubt that the business tone has taken a different tenor in the last two years, Scott.

And you have to wonder what that means for this market. We know there's an old saying on Wall Street that bull markets don't die of old age. But there's so many folks out there reluctant to get in this market, even though they see their own personal fortunes improving.

MARTIN: Yes, and, Charles, it goes across the board. It's from large multinational industrials to a small business owner like myself that, to Gary's point, sees that better regulatory environment, the better tax environment that we have seen.

And that helped kind of unleash that next level of growth that I think everybody kind of is waiting for here, even trade deal or not. So I think that's really good. And I like Susan's point, too, about kind of the cleanest dirty shirt in the basket here. And I will throw another one to her. You know, the U.S. is still kind of like the strongest guy or girl at the beach.

And so that's another reason why if you're an investor here and you see pullbacks like we have seen in the S&P 500 this year alone on, say, controversial or maybe good or bad economic data, that's why I would take that as an opportunity to get in and put some money to work.

PAYNE: Rebecca, 20,000 jobs reported for last month. Perhaps that gets revised higher. By the same token, though, the wage number was absolutely phenomenal.

And what I think people aren't talking about, the Federal Reserve is not going to get in the way. They're going to let America, Americans get a raise. What does that mean for the economy and the stock market?

WALSER: Yes, I mean, Charles, like you said, we had wage growth and we had the unemployment actually drop.

So we actually even had January revised upwards to 311,000. So, if we look at the trends, six months looks good, three months looks good. The fundamentals are still there. I don't think the market needs to overreact. It overreacted a little bit this morning. Now you it's pulled back and kind of normalized.

We expect -- the underlying fundamentals are the best in the world. Are we going to have the fact that we have an aged bull market here having some impact and some economic creep in from China and the E.U.? Obviously, it affects us. We still are, as you said, Scott, the best in the world.

PAYNE: All right, double-edged sword that there's not a lot of enthusiasm about the market. Most experts say that's one of the reasons why it's going to keep going higher.

But we have got some -- I want to thank our experts on this panel. Thank you all very much. Appreciate it.

WALSER: Thanks, Charles.

PAYNE: You know, despite today's big jobs miss, the president sounding very upbeat on the economy.

John Roberts it at the White House with more on that -- John.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Charles, one of the things that's overhanging the economy, at least this month, is, as Susan Li was pointing to, is whether or not there is a trade deal between the United States and China.

We were expecting that there was going to be a meeting Mar-a-Lago at the end of this month between President Trump and Xi Jinping, the president of China. It now looks like that's not going to happen.

FOX News has learned that the Chinese had time pencilled in, blocked out for Xi Jinping to come to Mar-a-Lago at the end of March. They have removed that time from his calendar. And I'm told there is no plan on the American side for a meeting in March now.

That's why Amazon has done so well, not because they're doing anything illegal. And, in fact, she literally said this morning that their purchase of Whole Foods was illegal.

On what basis is that illegal?

PAYNE: Real quick, we only have 30 seconds, but what about the idea that it's not hurting the customer, but it's hurting small businesses?

DODSON: Well, I think that's absurd, because if you look at how many -- for example, how many books have been published, self-published books on Amazon, it reached a million this year. Never before.

More things are sold by regular people over the Internet now as a result of the democratization of the Internet, whether it's all the way from eBay back in the day, to Amazon, to Facebook and so forth.

PAYNE: Right.

DODSON: So these are places where people have an opportunity to sell products.

PAYNE: David, thank you very much.

Really appreciate it.

DODSON: Not at all.

PAYNE: Well, big tech played a big role in keeping this bull market running, so be sure to tune in to "Cavuto Live" tomorrow at 10:00 a.m. Eastern for special coverage on the bull market's 10-year anniversary.

In the meantime, I will be back on Monday at 2:00 p.m. Eastern for "Making Money" on the FOX Business Network. We will see you then, again, tomorrow, 10 years, bull market, big deal.

So is "The Five." It starts right now.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5V9X-3JM1-DXH2-6009-00000-00Interview With Rep. Sean Duffy (R-WI); Polar Vortex Brings Record Cold, Wind Chill Warning In Effect; China-U.S. Discuss Possible Trump-Xi Summit Just Before Trade Deal; Pentagon: Several Thousand More Troops Heading to the Southern Border; Facebook Soars on Earnings2019-01-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:23ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTSean Duffy; Ross Stripling, Bill RichardsonNEWSDomestic013103cb.231Interview With Rep. Sean Duffy (R-WI); Polar Vortex Brings Record Cold, Wind Chill Warning In Effect; China-U.S. Discuss Possible Trump-Xi Summit Just Before Trade Deal; Pentagon: Several Thousand More Troops Heading to the Southern Border; Facebook Soars on EarningsMaria Bartiromo, Mike Huckabee, James Freeman, Dagen McDowell, Susan Li, Janice Dean, Blake Burman, Stuart Varney

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it Thursday, January 31st. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. It is the busiest day for earnings so far, General Electric out last hour. The stock keeps rising over the last hour. It is now up better than nine percent on better-than-expected revenue in the fourth quarter.

We have an eye on big tech this morning. Facebook soaring this morning on a record profit reported last night, stock is up 11-3/4 percent even in the face of the privacy scandal. The stock to watch after the close, Amazon. Amazon shares right now up two percent. The company reports earnings after the close tonight. Markets this morning are looking at a mixed open for the broader averages.

Take a look. Dow Industrials right now down 36 points but the S&P 500 is up two and the NASDAQ, higher by 35 points right now. This after a sharp rally yesterday fueled by Federal Reserve. The Dow Industrials up 435 points at the close yesterday. 1-3/4 percent. The S&P 500 up 41, 1-1/2 percent and the NASDAQ up 155 points, up 2-1/4 quarter percent. And the Federal Reserve officially told us they are on hold in terms of data dependency on interest rate hikes.

Global markets this morning look like this. The European indices right now are most higher. FT-100 up 35 points, one-half of one percent. CAC Quarante in Paris up 3-1/2 points, fractional move. DAX index in Germany down 38 points, one-third of one percent. In Asia overnight, mixed performances, take a look, best performer is Hong Kong and Japan, each up better than one percent.

Back in U.S. The arctic blast has turned deadly. Temperatures across the Midwest falling to their levels in decades.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It's like hard to take a breath and it stick to my lungs a little bit.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The winds, the windchill is probably the worst of it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We have a look at when millions of Americans can expect temperatures to fall. We will tell you. Plus this, attacking the wealthy again. Former Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz answers critics about his success. Then Roger Goodell breaks his silence. What he said about the infamous no call during the NHC championship game later this hour.

All those stories coming this Thursday morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the Wall Street Journal's assistant editorial page editor, James Freeman. And former Arkansas governor, Republican presidential candidate, Mike Huckabee. Good to see you this morning.

MIKE HUCKABEE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Thank you very much.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good to be here. The kind of interesting we've been talking about for the last year really, Facebook, how much do users care about these privacy issues. And last summer we got those results looked look like maybe users aren't really digging this but this latest numbers, you got to say, it looks like users care less about the privacy issues than those of us in media.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And then they have other areas other than the Facebook business to monetize. Like with WhatsApp, Messenger, which they're not actually getting any advertising from so far. So one thing not monetize those think there's an expectations from a business perspective that there's going to be even more growth

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Instagram is kind of the great juggernaut that they have -- or that they're growing, incredibly rapidly but I point this out that because Apple banned this basically data gathering app where they were getting young people in teens to give them all data this is Facebook, Apple bans it, well -- from this app store. You know what's interesting? That self-regulation.

Again, it's not going to be the government that comes in, it's going to be all of these tech companies maybe regulating each other and realizing it might be in their best business interests to not just help them grow incredibly strong but also limit their growth.

HUCKABEE: I'm more worried about Facebook censoring content. I don't mean the censoring the classic sense of the government but deciding what people get to see, that worries me more than the privacy issue. When you sign up for Facebook, you know you're giving away privacy.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FREEMAN: Yes.

HUCKABEE: But you don't realize is that Facebook is picking for you what you get to see and with 60 percent of Americans now getting most of their news from Facebook. That's really disturbing.

BARTIROMO: This is what the Congress is looking at and that's why got those guys, Facebook, Google executives to testify. Last year in Capitol Hill to see if in fact they are censoring conservative conversation.

HUCKABEE: And they are.

BARTIROMO: You mentioned Instagram, check out our Instagram post today, it is throwback Thursday. And posted a shot of way back in 1985, you posted a shot of yourself in the 80s. Where is your picture? Post your picture from throwback Thursday Instagram. I'm having the best time on Instagram.

MCDOWELLL: If I looked like you did in the 80s, I would be posting throwback photos while -- may even look like you now but --

BARTIROMO: You look gorgeous.

MCDOWELLL: No, no. Maria looks like Sophia Loren and I look -- well, not so --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Oh, come on. Throwback Thursday.

FREEMAN: A lot of good looks.

BARTIROMO: We've got some good looks this morning. So check out our Instagram pages. Meanwhile, we've got a big hour coming up. Joining the conversation this morning, Wisconsin Congressman and House Financial Services Committee member Sean Duffy is here. Former Ambassador to the U.N., Bill Richardson is with us. Along with L.A. Dodger pitcher Ross Stripling joining us this morning.

And the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney weighs in as always. Don't miss a moment of it. We kick it off right here with this. General Electric shares are soaring this morning on strong earnings. Susan Li is on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with the details. Stock is up nine percent, Susan. Good morning to you.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Yes. Good morning to you, Maria. And congratulations for mastering Instagram. We'll talk about Facebook in just a bit. But yes, G.E. shares are higher rallying in the premarket and this is because they got a revenue beat, it's actually pretty good for G.E. as you know, it's been shrinking. There's been problems with the company. But aviation was strong for G.E. in the quarter and that offset the slowdown.

And so as some problems that we're seeing in the capital business and also their power businesses as well. G.E. also by the way settling that DOJ subprime settlements of just around $1-1/2 billion. This goes back to the 2008 financial crisis. And as you know, they have been spinning off several businesses in 2018 to spring off some cash flow and to try to make some profit.

Let's talk about Facebook because also rallying in the premarket, Faceboook shares and as you mentioned stories doing very well for them on Instagram and also on Facebook as well. And they grew, daily active users and all geographic locations and this is after a downturn of course in Europe and also plateau in North America. So that's important to watch. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Susan. Thank you so much. Meanwhile, U.S.-China trade, the President tweeting about it this morning saying this, China's top trade negotiators are in the United States meeting with our representatives. Meeting are going well with good intent and spirit on both sides. China does not want to -- an increase in tariffs and feels they will do much better if they make a deal, they're correct.

I will be meeting with their top leaders and representatives today in Oval Office, no final deal will be made until my friend, President Xi and I meet in the near future to discuss and agree on some of the longstanding and more difficult points. Very comprehensive transaction. Writes the President. He goes on to say, Chinese representatives and I are trying to do a complete deal leaving nothing unresolved on the table.

All of the many problems are being discussed and will be hopefully revolved. Tariffs on China increased to 25 percent on March 1st. So, all working hard to complete by that date. My next guest is the cosponsor of a bill that will give President Trump executive power to raise tariffs and joining me right now is Wisconsin Congressman, House Financial Services Committee member, Sean Duffy. Congressman, it's good to see this morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

REP. SEAN DUFFY (R), WISCONSIN: It's good to be with you, Maria. Thanks for having me on.

DOBBS: So in the President's tweet just now, he said everything is on the table, all of these tough issues, does that mean that he is also talking about espionage, the forced transfer of technology and the I.P. theft?

DUFFY: Absolutely. I think he is talking about all these issues. When you have a relationship with trading partner like China, you can't do business for very long. We have a country like China stealing our intellectual property or the force transfer of intellectual property. So, yes. No, this is all on the table. Here's what I think is going on now, Maria. We understand that China lies and they cheat and they steal, right?

So we want to get a deal before March 1st so we don't have that increase in tariffs. But I don't know that all the other tariffs currently imposed are going to come off on March 1st if a deal is struck because even if you get a deal with China, are they going to implement the deal? And that's going to take time. So, we got to actually -- we don't have this trust but verify like Reagan said with the Russians.

We have I think a philosophy of don't trust and verify with the Chinese because we -- they can sign a document with us, an agreement with us but that doesn't mean they're going to implement that document. So, folks, if a deal comes and tariffs are lifted, I don't think that's a strategy right now.

BARTIROMO: And we know that because they did that on beef, right? They said that they would buy certain amount of beef and then they didn't.

DUFFY: Right. Yes. You're absolutely correct. And, so, you know, again, I -- we believe in free trade and we think, you know, having a great trading partner like China where we can, you know, lower tariffs and respect each other's intellectual property is a great relationship but when you see the rising threat of China militarily and their -- and their substantial growth, we have to take a second look at, you know, what they're doing and what risk that poses to our to American way one of life.

And by the way, Maria, what's -- you know, what President Trump has done brilliantly is, you know, because of these tariffs but also, you know, the knowledge of the force transfer of technology, you see the whole global supply chain changing away from China. And you can't do business for that long when you steal a technology to people who come to your country.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

DUFFY: And Americans are getting -- China is not a good home for business. There's other places that we can go outside of China and it's having a real impact even on American earnings as you reported are American companies missing some of their numbers, Apple, Nvidia because of lack of sales that are happening inside of China because of the slowdown that has been led by Donald Trump --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Well, you know, it's interesting because we actually had Steve Ballmer on a couple of months ago, former CEO of Microsoft and he said that the theft from China costs Microsoft $10 billion in profits because 90 percent of the companies in China use the Microsoft operating system only a fraction, one percent actually pay for it. So, there's all of this theft going on.

What are the metrics that you want to use to check to verify that in fact if you do do a deal that they will follow through on it? And do I hear you saying that there is no way that tariffs are going to be gone? That you can't lift tariffs at all because you can't trust what they say they're going to follow through on?

DUFFY: Yes. I think metric is time, Maria. I mean, we have to give this time to see with actual implementation. And so I don't know if that's a year or two years, I think -- I think you have a longer runway here on the tariff front with China but you might mentioned intellectual property I think the Chinese are suing us at the WTO for $50 billion of tariffs that President Trump put on the Chinese for intellectual property theft.

And our analysis is that they steel $250 to $600 billion a year of American technology and they're -- they have their goal to sue us over the $50 billion in tariffs. I mean, this is rich stuff with the Chinese and I just -- I think we have a president -- President Trump who's willing to actually fight this out for the American people and try to win for our country.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Let me -- let me switch gears and ask you about Foxconn, a major reversal. We talked about you in the electronics' giant first announced their new Wisconsin factory that was supposed to bring blue collar manufacturing jobs. Now the research centers for scientists and engineers. Congressman, what about the manufacturing jobs, how disappointed are you by this reversal?

DUFFY: So they're still -- they're still committed to the R&D side of it but you're right on the manufacturing side. They haven't necessarily pulled out but they have signaled that they will on the manufacturing side of Foxconn. And Maria, first of all, so they invested $100 million in the University of Wisconsin system to train our workers. That's fantastic. They bought buildings, they have land to build their facilities.

But what's happening, Wisconsin, why is this decision made? Scott Walker lost. The guy that won, Tony Evers in Wisconsin was bashing this deal from the very beginning. So now you have an unfriendly government in Wisconsin who doesn't want Foxconn there. This a massive investment. And if you're going to make it, you better have a governor who goes, yes, you know, come to my state, bring us the jobs, I'm happy to have you.

And that's hasn't been Tony Evers. And so, they've been attacking this deal from the very beginning. I don't think this will happen if Scott Walker had won in Wisconsin but it is now because, you know, business -- Foxconn is under attack in our state because of our new governor.

BARTIROMO: Wow. So you -- so you blame the new governor as --

DUFFY: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: For this, how many jobs will be cut then?

DUFFY: Well, so they haven't walked away. They had a promise of 13 million jobs to $10-billion investment. They haven't walked away from that number. And by the way, the incentives that we gave for Foxconn to come were tied to the investment and the jobs. And so they just missed a $10- million incentive because they didn't hit the job number. So, again, this is still up in the air for us but if you're Foxconn, you really have to consider the politics of our state and what's changed in the last, you know, two months.

BARTIROMO: Wow. All right. Before you go, what are you dealing with, negative 26 degrees right there in Wisconsin, Congressman?

DUFFY: Yes. So, it's 27 below, windchills hit up to 50 below, just have been -- people don't get this in the south but our cars don't start here. The post office, it never shuts down, the post office is shut down.

BARTIROMO: Oh my god.

DUFFY: Our ski hill is shut down. My Congressional office yesterday was shut down. People couldn't get to work. So, you know, it's crazy cold and by the way, kids, we have eight kids, seven of them are at home, you coop up kids for two days in the house because they can't go outside.

BARTIROMO: Oh my god.

DUFFY: Crazy fights are going and you can only watch so many movies, Maria, and play some of the games monopoly before your house is ready to explode.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: I mean, the whole Midwest experiencing the coldest temperatures in decades, so they're staying home from school, right?

DUFFY: Yes. You can't send these little kids out waiting, you know, for a bus to go to school. I mean, listen you people get hurt in this kind of weather. So it breaks today, this afternoon we start to see a breaks. We go from minus 27, I think we have a high today of minus four. That's the heat wave that's coming our way.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

DUFFY: And if I can make one last point, Maria, I just watch through the 80s and 90s, I have pull up Instagram pictures of your throwback Thursday. Huge fan when you're on other networks, I'm a huge fan of you here. So --

BARTIROMO: Thank you.

DUFFY: -- I'm looking forward too. If Dagen is up, so we're going to check out Dagen from back in the 80s.

BARTIROMO: Congressman, thank you so much.

DUFFY: You know, she has some big, you know, 80s hair.

BARTIROMO: I love the throwback Thursday, yes. Well, that picture that I posted in the Instagram is from 1985. Post your picture, Congressman. Thank you so much.

DUFFY: I got some really bad ones too. I got big old -- yes. Thanks.

BARTIROMO: I'll see you soon. Sean Duffy joining us there. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well, the Midwest is facing the coldest temperatures in decades. The extreme freeze is turning deadly. Fox News Senior Meteorologist Janice Dean in the Weather Center right now with the very latest. Janice?

JANICE DEAN, FOX NEWS SENIOR METEOROLOGIST: Hi, Maria. Yes. Unfortunately, we're going to have one more day of this and then the cold air will start to retreat but you can see the windchill is most dangerous part of this cold air. Is across the northern plains, the great lakes, now into the northeast where it feels like minus 13 in New York, it feels like zero in D.C. but minus 40 Fargo, minus 41 is what it feels like in Chicago.

Those incredible pictures coming out of Chicago of the rivers just freezing. Green Bay, air temperature, minus 23, windchill minus 23, air temperature in Chicago by the way is minus 21 but it is the windchill that's potentially deadly. That's why people are urged to stay indoors. If you've got kids, if you got pets and you want to check on the elderly. Today will be the really cold day and things will start to improve Friday.

But windchill advisories and warnings in place for millions of people where the windchill is anywhere from minus 25 to minus 60 especially across the northern plains in the upper Midwest. OK. So here is our polar vortex that is dipped as far south as the Tennessee River Valley, Ohio. By Saturday it retreats up into Canada but we're not done yet heading into Monday. We start to see it move southward again across the plain states across the great lakes.

So we're not done. Now, this cold air, the really cold air is probably done for the season but we're still going to see below freezing temperatures as we get into next week. But I will tell you as we head into the weekend, Maria, look at this, so minus one, today is the daytime high for Minneapolis but will be in the 40s by Sunday. And then, Monday, things will start to come down again.

Here is Chicago where we are dealing with minus 40 degree windchills, by Saturday and Sunday even Monday, 53 degrees. I mean, that is a 60-degree temperature difference from today and Monday. So something we're going to have to watch. These are weather extremes. Certainly, we'll watch it. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Janice. Thanks so much. Janice Dean with the latest there. Coming up. We are watching markets this morning on last trading day of the month today. Busiest day for earnings. Dow Industrials down 51, S&P and NASDAQ up. Next up, L.A. Dodgers pitcher turns stock broker, Ross Stripling in the house with his take on market action.

Then breaking his silence, NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell finally speaks out on the controversial no call that knocked the Saints off the path to the Super Bowl. What he had to say right after this.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets in focus this morning, futures indicating a mixed opening for the markets this morning on this. The last trading day of the month. Dow Industrials expected to be down 60 points, S&P and the NASDAQ are higher fractionally. This after the major indices rallied yesterday big time after the Federal Reserve indicated it has done raising interest rates for now, it will be data dependent.

But the Dow Industrials were as high as 500 points, better than 500. it ended up 434 on the Dow. 154 points higher on the NASDAQ. Joining us right now is Los Angeles Dodgers all-star pitcher and B. Riley Wealth Management stock broker, Ross Stripling. Ross, it's great to see you this morning. Thanks so much for being here.

ROSS STRIPLING, STOCK BROKER, B. RILEY WEALTH MANAGEMENT: Good morning, Maria. Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Well, we got to talk sports but we want to first talk money. Tell us what you think about what you heard from the Fed yesterday and how you're telling clients to allocate capital right now.

STRIPLING: Yes. You know, that was definitely optimistic, you know, coming out and saying that, you know, our economy is growing, spending is strong, they're going to be patient moving forward with the -- with the rate hikes, you know, October, November, December were certainly ugly for me as a -- as a growth investor, you know, that got out of hand but, you know, I definitely think we got oversold.

And, you know, so we're kind of telling investors, you know, it's a good time to be patient and a good time to be, you know, long-term mined I think if you think back to January 2016,you know, it definitely got oversold in that month and then all the market did was rally 10,000 points over the next two years. So, I think it's a good time to be patient, you're getting a good -- so you can get some good names at low valuations and obviously, get some of that money back lost that we lost late last year.

BARTIROMO: All right.

FREEMAN: Can we go to baseball questions?

BARTIROMO: Yes. Go for it.

FREEMAN: OK. So -- I apologize, I didn't watch this when it happened but Wikipedia says, your very first major league start, you had no hitter into the 7th inning and you got pulled out.

STRIPLING: Yes, yes.

FREEMAN: So this is --

STRIPLING: Yes. Thanks for bringing that back up. No, I'm just kidding.

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: Basically, the highs and lows of baseball in your first professional appearance.

STRIPLING: Yes. I mean, man, if you just think about what goes into the - - to a debut of Major League Baseball, I mean, I was just so nervous that day and then to finally get up to game time and then to -- like you said, to be able to go over seven innings of no-hit baseball and then -- and then you get pulled. I mean, it happens so fast, you know, and I certainly thought about it more since then that, you know, things that will never get to know how would have finished but I've always said that I understood the decision to pull me out.

I was coming off for Tommy John surgery, I've already thrown a hundred pitches, that was the most I've thrown in two years. So, you know, we'll never know how it would have ended like I said but I've have always been open about understanding that decision and, you know, maybe I'll get another shot and no-hitter someday.

MINERD: Hey, Ross, this is Mike Huckabee and one of the things that I'm most intrigue by is your use of data to prepare for ballgames. It sounded like a real-life version of Moneyball in modern times. So explain how do you collect the data and how do you go about using that to plan your own pitching strategy because I think that's fascinating.

STRIPLING: Sure. You know, I'll try and give you the shortest version of that question as possible. And, you know, the Dodgers are probably kind of leading the way in all that, you know, analytics and things like that. So we have a whole division that kind of gets the data for me and I mean, they can give you as much as you want and I -- at first when I got up I wanted it all, just give me all the data possible and I will just get what I want out of it.

But now, after three years, you know, you got to cut it down to what you want which is usually, you know, what guys slug in certain counts, what they hit the hardest, what's their biggest swing and missed pitch. You can even look like what the man on second base, you know, do they get more aggressive. There's just tons of data out there, so you kind of pick and choose what you want and use it when you're on the mound.

That way you're not just like boggled down with data while you're on the mound, you know, at the end of the day you just got to trust your ability to get major league hitters out but you want to use to it come up with a plan and each guy is different and you go over with your pitching coach and your catcher and all of that and you have a plan against every batter, one through nine for any situation and --

BARTIROMO: That is --

STRIPLING: -- you know, that's kind of thought. Yes.

BARTIROMO: That is really smart. Let me ask you before you go, Ross, Super Bowl 53, three days away, who are you betting on? Your hometown Rams or the Patriots?

STRIPLING: Yes. I got to go hometown Rams. I think McVay have some up his sleeve that Bellatrix never seen and they made a lot of acquisitions in offseason on that defense, maybe they can get a big stop on Brady. So I'll take the Rams.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll be watching. Ross, great to have you this morning. Thanks so much.

STRIPLING: Thank you, guys. Have a good one.

BARTIROMO: Ross Stripling joining us. Make sure you tune in tomorrow, we'll bring you live coverage of the January jobs' report starting at 8:00 a.m. Eastern. That should set the tone for markets, so be here right at that time tomorrow when we set the tone for the day. Coming up. Border Wall funding battle. Lawmakers kicking off talks to fund the wall as the Pentagon deploys more troops.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, January 31st. Your top stories right now 8:32 a.m. on the East Coast.

Breaking news, Weekly Jobless Claims hitting the tape just now. The number, 253,000 higher than the expectation which calls for 215,000. Markets have worsened a bit. DowDuPont down, as you see, 8-1/4 percent on a mixed earnings report. And Facebook is up 11-1/4 percent this morning, better-than- expected earnings last night after the close.

Mixed action this morning for the markets. As you just saw, Dow Industrials down 66. This is just around the low of the morning for the Dow Industrials, and the S&P has been positive for much of the day, but has just turned negative. NASDAQ is still up 25 points. In Europe this morning, the major indices are mostly higher. The FT-100 this morning looks like this, up 36 points off of the highs of the morning, a half of a percent higher in London. BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Maria, good morning to you as well. Just moments ago, he sent out the following tweet about that group saying the following quote, "Republicans on the Homeland Security Committee are wasting their time. Doesn't need necessarily need to be called a wall. He's backing off that today as well because he tweeted this this morning, "Let's just call them wolves from now on, and stop political games, a wall is wall, give you a pretty good idea of where his mindset is after just one meeting from this group up on Capitol Hill. Meantime, the Pentagon says that several thousand more troops are going to be heading to the Southern Border. The Undersecretary for policy testifying up on Capitol Hill earlier this week that several caravans are headed north.

BURMAN: Didn't get an exact number from the Pentagon, Maria. Currently, there are 2,500 give or take active duty service members down at the Southern border. That is down from a high of nearly 6,000, but the pentagon says several thousand more are headed that way. Maria.

RICHARDSON: Well, the first thing you need to do is the President needs to get off this idea that unless he gets his way, there's going to be a government shutdown. RICHARDSON: Well, Mike, first of all, the tactics that are being used to get that wall, which I think is very dubious to build because I don't think it'll work and it's too expensive is that if the President doesn't get his way, he's going to shut down the government, and he's going to do harm to 800,000 Federal workers, businesses, and then this wall, Mike, I mean it's going to take landowners out of there, it's going to take ranchers, indigenous people, wildlife. You're right, and most of the border, you can't build the wall because of the hills, because of the terrain, so --

HUCKABEE: But Bill he has been very flexible in saying that it's a combination of all of those things, it's not just a wall. But you say he's not been willing to give.
