Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X41-7T51-DXH2-64SK-00000-00Interview with Rudy Giuliani about Ukraine Call; President Donald Trump Calls for Probe of Former Vice President Joe Biden amid Ukraine Call Scrutiny; Reports: Some WeWork Board Members Seek to Remove CEO Adam Neumann; Interview with Rep. Guy Reschenthaler (R-PA)2019-09-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:24ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTRudy Giuliani, Ryan Payne, Mitch Roschelle, Guy Reschenthaler, Randy EssexNEWSFinancial092302cb.231Interview with Rudy Giuliani about Ukraine Call; President Donald Trump Calls for Probe of Former Vice President Joe Biden amid Ukraine Call Scrutiny; Reports: Some WeWork Board Members Seek to Remove CEO Adam Neumann; Interview with Rep. Guy Reschenthaler (R-PA)Maria Bartiromo, Susan Li, Liz Peek, James Freeman, Cheryl Casone

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. Happy Monday.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Monday, September 23rd.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast.

Futures are off of the lows this morning, take a look. Dow Industrials are still negative, down 12 points. But the S&P 500 has turned positive. It's up 1.75. And the Nasdaq is also 5 and above 14.

This on top of last week where the Dow, the Nasdaq and the S&P posted a losing week. But they are still within striking distance of hitting all- time highs. Last week the Dow was down about 1 percent on the week.

Global markets this morning look like this. In Europe today, we are looking at a down session. Ft 100 down 28 points, a third of a percent. CAC 40 in Paris is down 53, that's almost 1 percent. And the DAX index in Germany 131 points right now, better than 1 percent.

There were signs of a slowdown in Europe, manufacturing sentiment in the eurozone down in September to the worst level in seven years. We also got the PMI, the purchasing manager's index is out of Germany and France this morning, they came in well below expectations.

In Asia overnight, mixed market there. Japan is closed for a national holiday. The Shanghai was down almost 1 percent in China.

The General Motors strike meanwhile is entering is entering day eight. Reports say important progress has been made but we could still be far from seeing workers back on the assembly line.

We're going to have the very latest there as GM shares down this morning, about three-quarters of 1 percent.

The Saudi oilfield attack repairs could take months, not weeks. The steps Saudi Aramco is taking to get full production back online.

And then the CEO of Wework could be on the way out, Board members reportedly pushing to oust Adam Newman after the company delayed its IPO.

All those stories coming up this Monday morning. And joining me to break it all down. Payne Capital Management president, Ryan Payne is here. Fox News contributor, columnist for "The Hill", Liz Peek. And the Wall Street Journal's assistant editorial page editor James Freeman.

Great to see everybody this morning.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "WALL STREET JOURNAL". Good to be here. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We're talking about Ukraine. We're talking markets. What else is important this morning?

PEEK: We're talking Europe being stagnant and smug at the same time. Germany passes a green measure which does not allow them to -- and raises taxes at the same time. It's almost unimaginable.

The country is being run by committee and it's a mess, in my view.

BARTIROMO: Hey -- no wonder they've got negative interest rates in Europe.

PEEK: Yes, exactly.

BARTIROMO: They can't generate economic growth.

PEEK: It's incredible. I mean honestly, Germany has natural gas. Had they decided to exploit their natural gas reserves, their emissions would be going down which they're not. Yet they lecture us all the time. I mean it's really -- it's kind of crazy making honestly.

BARTIROMO: Is there any reason to buy Europe right now from your standpoint?

RYAN PAYNE, PAYNE MANAGEMENT: I love Europe.

BARTIROMO: You love -- well, from a stock standpoint.

PEEK: We're not talking about travel.

PAYNE: Well, now you just move (INAUDIBLE) standpoint. I mean look, we know the slowing has been kind of priced into the market. But I also think that remember, most European economies are running a surplus right now, besides Greece and France. And right now we have a $1 trillion deficit in the last 12 months.

So I mean they're balance sheets are actually --

BARTIROMO: But you saw those PMis.

PAYNE: We knew that, right. That wasn't a surprise. We knew manufacturing was going to slow but you have to look at their domestic economies. They've been relatively resilient here. I mean, you know, they haven't really gone that far into the negative.

And as an investor, you just have to love those low valuations right now.

BARTIROMO: Evaluations certainly are different than for the U.S. is in terms of valuations. I'll give you that.

Meanwhile our top story this hour, President Trump on the world stage this week. The U.N. General assembly kicking off today amid tense Middle East relations.

Iranian President Rouhani slamming the latest round of U.S. sanctions on the rogue regime as, quote, desperate, according to him.

And now, new this morning, the rogue regime also freeing a British tanker it seized back in July, ending a monthlong standoff with the U.K. ahead of the U.N. Summit.

I spoke exclusively this weekend with Senate Judiciary Committee chairman Lindsey Graham on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES".

He outlined how he would like to see the U.S. respond.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: What kind of a response do you want to see from the United States?

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: I hope the President will put on table a military option that will restore deterrence because sanctions are not enough.

I give the President a ton of credit for taking Iran on. But this is a defining moment in his presidency. I think President Trump has been strong on China, strong on ISIS, Strong on North Korea strong on Iran.

But the Iranians are acting out in a very dangerous way. By attacking the Saudi Arabian oilfield, they have attacked the world economy. It's in our national security interest to protect Mideast energy supplies even though we're less dependent. It is in our national security interest to protect the navigation of the seas.

And this is a rogue regime. Do to what Iran now what Reagan did to them in 80s when they acted up. You will restore deterrents Mr. President. They will not get in an all-out war with the United States because that will be the end of the regime.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is Pennsylvania Congressman, member of the Judiciary and Foreign Relations Committee and Iraq War Veteran -- Guy Reschenthaler.

And Congressman, it is good to see you this morning. Thanks very much for being here.

REP. GUY RESHENTHALER (R-PA): Thanks for having me on.

BARTIROMO: I mean given your experience -- thank you for your service to our great country, by the way --

RESCHENTHALER: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: So from your stand point, do you want to see a military option on the table for the U.S. to respond to Iran?

RESCHENTHALER: Well, I think we always need have a military option on the table. That helps us with deterrence. But I can tell you that, Iran is acting out. They've been acting out for several years. But it's heightened because of the maximum applied pressure the Trump administration is putting on the regime.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean Lindsey Graham and General Jack Keane, four star general will say if there is not a response from the United States, Iran will continue to poke and continue doing things to just get back at the U.S. because of taking the country out of the Iran Nuclear Deal.

RESCHENTHALER: Right. Well, that's absolutely correct. Iran will keep acting out. They're really trying to put pressure on Europe because they think that Europe will crack. They'll bend, they won't honor the sanctions. That's why we have to work really hard to make sure Europeans stand with us. That's why we need to make sure that these sanctions actually work.

But you're absolutely right. We can never take the military option off the table. If we do, then we lose all pressure we have on Iran.

FREEMAN: Congressman -- hi. James Freeman of the "Wall Street Journal". Speaking of potential military action, what about Saudi Arabia? Who you expect them to respond to Iran and is there a reason why they don't have that capability? I know they buy a lot of American military equipment. I think it's the third largest defense budget in the world.

RESCHENTHALER: Right. Well, you have to remember, Iran has one of the strongest militaries in the world and we are the hegemonic super power in the Middle East. We have put troops, more troops in Saudi Arabia. We're helping with their missile defense.

But if there is going to be an engagement, it will more than likely be one that's led by the United States, but, of course, alongside our allies such as Saudi Arabia.

PEEK: Congressman -- I have heard that there is no question that Iran was behind this attack, and yet France continues to question the evidence and so forth. France obviously has a different agenda and we want them on- board with our pushback to Iran.

What is it going to take to put them there? What is it that France is hoping to achieve by this kind middling ground?

RESCHENTHALER: Right. Well, we've got to keep the Europeans with us, and sadly the Europeans really have the most to lose because if they're not with us on sanctions, if they're not helping with diplomatic options, then it makes actual kinetic operations more likely which we all want to avoid.

So by standing with us, the French and the Europeans actually help us avoid an actual military engagement.

BARTIROMO: What about these waivers? I mean the U.S., you know, renewed those sanction waivers for nuclear programs and for Europeans to do business with Iran. I mean, is that the issue here, that the Europeans still want to buy gas from Iran?

RESCHENTHALER: Right. Well, the Europeans are much more susceptible to energy prices. We have to remember, the unsung hero here and that is frackers in the United States -- Pennsylvania and Texas.

If we didn't have natural gas development in the United States, we would probably be in a recession, oil prices would be skyrocketing.

Because the Europeans, particularly the Germans, won't allow fracking and horizontal drilling, they're much more susceptible to market swings.

BARTIROMO: Well, somebody needs to tell the Germans about what the U.S. has been doing so that the Germans understand they don't necessarily need Iran for this.

RESCHENTHALER: Right. Well, drilling for natural gas is a win on all fronts because you have energy independence or you move toward energy independence. Your carbon emissions are reduced because natural gas is much cleaner.

I wish that the Europeans would take a look at our boom -- our natural gas boom, and see what we're exporting energy, that we're much less susceptible to the whims of the OPEC nations. Unfortunately, they're not.

BARTIROMO: What about this impeachment inquiry, controversy swirling around the president's July phone call with Ukrainian president. The president admitted that he did discuss former vice president Joe Biden on the call and that's sparking calls for impeachment once again. Is this more Russia collusion speculation all over again?

RESCHENTHALER: Well, as far as the so-called whistleblower, let's see what the whistleblower says to the House Intel and the Senate Intel Committees when the whistleblower comes to testify.

But I can tell you that for impeachment, the American people don't want to go down this road. And unfortunately Jerry Nadler has taken the bait. He's trying to appease his far left radical base. He can have -- what I would call impeachment lite in the Judiciary Committee.

We have got to remember that for impeachment proceedings to begin the entire floor has to vote on that. The democrats have tried three times to call for impeachment and they failed three times on the floor.

So they're trying to have their cake and eat it too. With Jerry Nadler having this faux impeachment style proceedings in the House Judiciary Committee.

BARTIROMO: Yes. the problem is, it's so irresponsible, I think, because I mean even today there's almost like half of America still thinks that there's a possibility of collusion.

I mean the bad information and the misinformation coming out as a result of these calls, the Democrats and the media, is really irresponsible. And I think that's one of the reasons that the Chinese reneged on that deal that the U.S. had in place. He said they were 90 percent there back in April. Because China is over there thinking that oh, well I'm going to be done with this guy in a couple years because of the collusion story.

Congressman -- it's good to see you this morning. Thank you.

RESCHENTHALER: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: I've got to get your take. And to you -- we appreciate you joining us. We'll see you soon.

Want to get your take on this next breaking news story -- guys. Snap reportedly been in talks with the Federal Trade Commission regarding Facebook.

Snap is compiling a dossier of ways Facebook attempted to thwart competition, according to Dow Jones. The reports also says its start up founders who sold their companies to Facebook are also talking to the FTC. Looks like everybody is getting on board to take Facebook down.

FREEMAN: Yes. We'll it's going to be going to be interesting. Because this question of what is the consumer harm has been looming behind all of this and the regulators have said we're going to look at a lot of these big techs including Facebook, to see their level of dominance in the market and the impact.

And it hasn't been entirely clear what exactly they were looking at and what they were planning to allege if they're going to bring a case on consumer harm. So maybe this is now something concrete that we can evaluate and discuss.

PEEK: But the answer here, the solution is not going back and investigating the Instagram acquisition by Facebook. It is preventing further acquisitions because new startups will challenge this company and Google and other companies. If the government is serious about anti-trust, that's what they should focus on.

I mean I think a lot of this is political show but there is an issue here.

BARTIROMO: But how serious is the issue of censoring of conservative conversation? Right now, you've got Devin Nunes suing Twitter. You've got Tulsi Gabbard suing Google for all of these reasons, for that reason of censorship.

PEEK: I think it's a very serious issue. If you go back and look at some of the complaints, it's not a joke. It's not something that right wing people have sort of made up out of thin air.

BARTIROMO: Right.

PEEK: There is definitely a political bias. When they say it's just the algorithms -- those algorithms are written by people. Those people have a bias and it shows up in the way they write the algorithm.

BARTIROMO: Well, it's important because, you know, I mean big tech -- when you Google something during 2016, during the election there, you Google Hillary Clinton -- you got all best thing since sliced bread stories. Then you Google Donald Trump, and it was all he's horrible, he's this and that.

I mean: the way that they set up the search results was biased.

PEEK: No question.

FREEMAN: Well, they've gone with this algorithm excuse or honest mistake excuse but Josh Holly tweeted last week that Zuckerberg told him, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg that it was bias in one of the recent episodes where they essentially blocked some conservative content.

So it's going to be interesting what comes out of that. There was no more algorithm excuse with that one apparently.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. We've got a lot to talk about this morning. We've a big show. Joining the conversation, President Trump's lawyer and former New York City mayor Rudy Giuliani is here this morning. Along with White House press secretary for President Trump and the first lady, Melania Trump, Stephanie Grisham is joining us this morning along with House Judiciary committee ranking member Georgia Congressman Doug Collins.

We've got a big two hours coming up. Don't miss a moment of it coming up next.

And then first, Aramco worries. The Saudi state oil giant says that repairs to its facilities may take longer than expected. The impact on crude coming up.

Then workers at Wework, company board members looking to oust the CEO. We will take a look at whether this will put the IPO back on track. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Tropical storms bearing down on Puerto Rico and Bermuda this morning. Cheryl Casone with headline now -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Yes. the season is under way, Maria.

Karen (ph) is moving across the southeastern Caribbean Sea, prompting tropical storm warnings for Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands as well. Heavy rain and flooding expected for this week.

And then you've got, tropical storm Jerry -- which could pass near Bermuda tomorrow night. That storm is packing sustained winds of up to 65 miles per hour.

We're also watching this across the pond, Saudi Aramco's repairs could take months longer than the company originally expected. This is what contractors are saying according to the wall street journal this morning. Aramco is in emergency talks with service providers, offering to pay a premium rate for a speedy recovery and rebelled. But it could take months instead of the 10 weeks so it's a promise by Aramco. Two Aramco sites hit during attacks back on September 14th.

And then there's this -- some progressive healthcare proposals by Democratic presidential candidates getting mixed reviews from voters. This is according to a new "Wall Street Journal"/NBC News poll.

So that survey found that two thirds of registered voters support expanding Medicare but more than half opposed -- get this Maria -- Medicare for all, that would replace private insurers.

Because according to the polling their current health insurance and don't want the government to run it.

BARTIROMO: Like hundreds of millions -- possibly. I don't know, 180 million people --

PEEK: Like all those UAW strikers. I mean that's always been something I could not understand why Democrats are so insistent on Medicare for all where their biggest constituents, the labor unions, have the best benefits on earth. That seems like a head scratcher.

BARTIROMO: Well, they're certainly upset this morning, once again at GM. We're entering strike week two, the UAW and GM still at odds over the contract, healthcare benefits included. The sticking points when we come back.

And then Disney dreams coming true with its streaming service now available for preorder. We've got all the details on that when we come right back. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The United Auto Workers strike against General Motors now in its second week. Both sides say they're still at odds but there are reports that important progress has been made.

Joining us right now is the "Detroit Free Press" senior content editor, Randy Essex (ph). Randy -- great to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

RANDY ESSEX, DETROIT FREE PRESS: Hi, good morning.

BARTIROMO: Can you walk us through the issues? What do the unions want specifically.

ESSEX: Well, the GM workers really want a way for temp workers, which is about 7 percent of GM's hourly workforce to get the same pay scale that the permanent workers have, to have the same benefits, to get profit sharing. That's been important to the GM workers.

The company isn't budging on that we heard yesterday. The company did say that it would keep the healthcare benefits that they have, which seems like a pretty big concession on the part of the company because that's a big expense.

But workers are insistent on temps and profit sharing. We reported -- go ahead.

BARTIROMO: No, no -- go ahead.

ESSEX: Well, we reported yesterday that the union has thought hard about staying out on strike after a tentative agreement is reached. That puts some pressure on GM because if the work stoppage goes a couple of weeks, the costs become much higher. If it's a shorter strike, they can ramp up production, the workers get overtime, they get a ratification bonus and, you know, the economic impact to both the company and the workers is a little less.

The economists here in Michigan also tell us that the effects really start to hit the state, which is, you know, auto workers concentrated here, so --

BARTIROMO: Right.

PEEK: Randy -- question for you. Are the temporary workers that you're talking about, are they members of the union? Is this something that's actually supposed to help those workers or help the union by allowing them to unionize?

ESSEX: They're already members of the union. They just -- back in the recession, the union made some concessions that allowed the companies, all the companies to hire proportion of temporary workers who make 15 to $18 an hour.

So it holds down company costs. Their benefits are different. They don't get profit sharing. They do get health insurance.

PAYNE: Randy -- another question for you. Ryan Payne here from Payne Capital. What about this electric car plant that they're using as a possible opportunity for some of these workers that's a way to kind of resolve this strike.

ESSEX: So two of the plants that in November GM said it would close, Detroit Hamtramck here and Lordstown in Ohio, which is of course getting a lot of publicity, it appears that those are being discussed as potential electric car or battery production facilities. Producing electric vehicles and batteries of course doesn't require as many workers. So you wouldn't see as many people in Lordstown, for example. And they probably will have some sort of joint venture. You know -- excuse me.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ESSEX: There's discussion about the electric car or electric truck company, workhorse, trying to put together a new enterprise to buy part of the Lordstown plant. So that seems to be factored in.

BARTIROMO: All real quick -- James.

FREEMAN: Yes. I'm just wondering, Randy, we mentioned the corruption case is ongoing against UAW leadership. Does that create a problem in terms of the incentive here that they have to prove they're doing an amazing job and not selling out their membership?

ESSEX: Yes -- we think that's a big factor in terms of ratification. So the -- we've been told and I think this is probably true, the workers tend to trust the layer down from the very top that is doing the negotiating. But when it comes to ratification, there's going to be some skepticism about whether they're getting the best deal that they can, which seems to be part of the reason that the union may be talking about leaving the workers out on strike after the tentative agreement is reached.

BARTIROMO: I see.

ESSEX: By the way, I do want to say, GM yielding on healthcare, apparently yielding on healthcare, that could be a problem when the negotiations turn to Ford because healthcare is a big deal for Ford. They have the largest number of U.S. hourly workers.

BARTIROMO: That's important, yes, good point. When is that negotiation are you expecting for Ford?

ESSEX: Well, the union picks one company to go first and it chose GM. Then it takes that tentative -- or that agreement as a template to the other two companies.

BARTIROMO: Sure.

ESSEX: Often that goes pretty smoothly but there could be hitches.

BARTIROMO: Randy -- thanks so much. Great to have you.

ESSEX: You're welcome.

BARTIROMO: Randy Essex joining us there.

Coming up, the Ukraine controversy, President Trump attorney and former New York City mayor Rudy Giuliani is next. He's here on the fallout from the President's phone call with his Ukrainian's counterpart.

Then trouble at Wework, reports putting the company's CEO on the hot seat, what it means for the IPO in the future. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Monday, September 23rd. Your top stories right now, 7:31 a.m. on the East Coast.

Markets are off of the lows this morning, take a look. Dow Industrials now down just 10 points, the S&P and the NASDAQ are positive with the NASDAQ up 15 points and the S&P up two points.

This after the markets posted a losing week last week, but all the major averages, Dow, NASDAQ, S&P are still just within striking distance of all- time highs.

Global markets this morning look like this, and as you will see, it is a weak story in the Eurozone. We have signs of slowing economy in Europe, manufacturing sentiment in the Eurozone fell in September. So the worst level in nearly seven years.

The Purchasing Managers' Index has came out today in Germany and France, they too well below expectations. The Manufacturing weakness has the major indices in Europe lower this morning.

FT-100 down 33, CAC Quarante down 53 and the DAX Index in Germany down 133 points.

Asian markets overnight look like this; Japan was closed overnight for a national holiday. The Shanghai Composite was down almost one percent that was the worst performer.

Investigating Facebook, Dow Jones this morning is reporting that Snap kept a dossier called Project Voldemort on the ways Facebook allegedly tried to thwart competition and it is speaking to lawmakers this morning.

WeWork's CEO could be on the way out, board members reportedly pushing out to oust Adam Neumann after the company delayed its IPO.

And then the streaming wars, new info, Disney Plus available for pre-order ahead of its big November debut. The stock is unchanged this morning.

All those stories coming up this Monday morning but first, our top story this half an hour, President Trump's July phone call with the president of Ukraine, the president reportedly pressured his Ukrainian counterpart to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden and his anti-trust investigations in Ukraine while his son Hunter Biden was working there.

I spoke with Senator Lindsey Graham yesterday on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" about that phone call. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Does the president have something to worry about in terms of that phone call he had with the leader of Ukraine?

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R-SC): I think every president would have a lot to worry about if this phone call is handled the way they're talking about.

Joe Biden said everybody's looked at this and found nothing. Who is everybody? Nobody's looked at the Ukraine and the Bidens. Nobody's look at the role the Ukraine played in the 2016 election.

I'm calling for somebody in the Justice Department to look at all things Ukraine. We've looked at all things Russia and Trump. His family, everything about his family, every transaction between the Trump campaign and Russia. Now it's time to see whether or not the Ukrainians released information regarding Manafort, who is Trump's campaign manager, what relationships if any did the Biden world have to the Ukraine. What role if any did the Ukraine play in the 2016 election?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Now, no response so far from the DOJ to Senator Lindsey Graham's call to investigate and probe all things Ukraine. We're waiting for that.

House Democrats say that this could ignite impeachment proceedings meanwhile.

Joining me right now is personal attorney for President Trump, former New York City Mayor, Mayor Rudy Giuliani. And Rudy, it's always a pleasure to see you. Let me ask you first though about the whistleblower. What do we know, who is this person where it's once again unidentified sources?

RUDY GIULIANI, ATTORNEY FOR PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP: Well, let's take a look at how the story has evaporated, kind of like Kavanaugh. It began with the president of the United States told the president-elect of Ukraine, I'm not going to give you $250 million if you don't investigate Biden. Money, quid pro quo kind of like what Biden did on tape, by the way.

Now the story's become no money was mentioned, no quid pro quo. Now we take out to the area of any kind of wrongdoing, we get into a propriety.

BARTIROMO: More speculation.

GIULIANI: But the Democrats, you know, wanted to impeach when it was quid pro quo in money. Now there's no quid pro quo, no money. A proper action by a president, they might say improper but certainly not grounds for impeachment.

As the story gets less serious, as the story disappears, they still want to impeach. So I hope the American people get the point. They want to impeach it doesn't matter.

BARTIROMO: Now we don't know --

GIULIANI: Here's the problem for them, even if you take the first story about the president, what Biden did is much worse. Much, much worse.

BARTIROMO: And I want to get to that because this is opening --

GIULIANI: But first of all it's --

BARTIROMO: This is opening up the spotlight on Biden. I want to get to that.

And If there's anybody -- if there's anybody in this country that doesn't think Biden did this to get his son out of trouble, then they need a little help.

BARTIROMO: But does the president give his skeptics sort of this stuff on a silver platter. I mean, you read the op-ed in the -- in the Journal today, Trump's Ukraine call, Mr. Trump's request showed bad judgment, they write. He was trying to draw a foreign leader into the middle of an American presidential politics.

GIULIANI: No, he wasn't. The Wall Street Journal -- first of all, the Wall Street Journal is dead wrong on the front page. The Wall Street Journal said that there was no accusation of wrong doing against Biden.

I told a reporter from the Wall Street Journal, would you go listen to the tapes? She wanted me to give it to her. I said go online. Listen to Kaleniuk tape, listen to the statement from Shokin -- read the statement from Shokin. Listen to the (INAUDIBLE) tape.

There are three tapes in which two prosecutors and another person in the Ukraine directly said that Biden did this to get his son out of trouble. And I'm going to have more facts tomorrow that prove it conclusively. But today we wanted to show that just in case you wanted to understand the criminality of this. Biden was paid a lot of money for this; there was one $3 million payment to the kid.

BARTIROMO: You said Ukraine gave Biden $3 million?

GIULIANI: A crooked company in the Ukraine called Burisma run by a guy who took $5 billion from Ukraine, pro-Russian --

BARTIROMO: And Biden was on the board of that company.

GIULIANI: Yes, and he was hired by a fugitive. He was hired by probably one of the worst organized criminals in Ukraine at the time. A guy named, Mykola Zlochevsky. Mykola Zlochevsky (INAUDIBLE) big-time criminal hired by -- hired Joe Biden two weeks after Joe Biden is named the czar for money to Ukraine.

They go hire Biden, Hunter Biden. They go hire a guy who is having a drug problem. He got thrown out of the military a few months earlier for drugs. Now, how did he get in the military? Joe pulled strings to get him in. The guy was like 37, 38. He was only there less than a year and he got caught with cocaine.

Now, you're going to put a kid on a board like this who's a cocaine abuser? And pay him a million dollars a year?

And here's how you pay him. They didn't give him a check; they didn't give him a wire. They sent his $3 million from Ukraine to Latvia, Latvia to Cyprus, Cyprus to the U.S.

When the prosecutor who got fired zeroed in on Cyprus and demanded the money, the Cyprian government told him that the U.S. Embassy, Obama's U.S. Embassy intervened and told them not to give the amount of money.

BARTIROMO: Look, I understand what you're saying.

GIULIANI: At that point -- at that point, the president of the Ukraine called him in and said Biden wants you fired. He had just zeroed in on the $3 million laundered to the son.

You don't get paid if it's legit. I prosecute a lot of people, Maria. This is like the best proof you can have of intent. It goes from Ukraine - - anybody here get paid that way? Ukraine, Latvia, Cyprus.

BARTIROMO: You make -- you make all the right points and I understand --

GIULIANI: And then they won't give the information.

BARTIROMO: The president's skeptics are not focused on that at all.

GIULIANI: Who cares about that?

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you, -- look, and I understand -- and I understand, and believe me, we just came off of the Russia collusion which I called that from the get-go.

But let me ask you this, did the president threaten to cut off aid to the Ukraine?

GIULIANI: No, that was a fault story.

BARTIROMO: 100 percent?

GIULIANI: Well, I can't tell you if it's 100 percent.

BARTIROMO: Because we know that the administration did delay U.S. aid to Ukraine, why?

GIULIANI: The Wall Street Journal also fails in its false article today, it fails to point out on the headlines on Saturday in the Ukraine, the Ukrainian version of the story.

The Ukrainian says, no pressure. The Foreign Minister of the Ukraine gave a speech and he said that he's pretty devastate, purview the conversation, there was no pressure.

BARTIROMO: OK.

GIULIANI: No pressure. Again, once again, the story is falling apart. No money mentioned. No quid pro quo. No quid pro quo means no pressure.

Now, who would know if there's pressure more than -- if the Ukrainian president didn't feel the pressure, there's no pressure.

BARTIROMO: Why would the president bring up Joe Biden and his son?

GIULIANI: Because Joe Biden --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Why do that (INAUDIBLE) why give your skeptics, your adversaries who are wanted to take you down anything to sort of bring up? That's really the question.

I mean, like, The Journal writes what we know of the call underscores Mr. Trump's greatest flaw as president.

GIULIANI: Oh, come on.

BARTIROMO: Which is his political narcissism. Every decision boils down to how it affects him or his re-election (INAUDIBLE)

And The key fact that there are three people that are accusing Biden of wrong doing and they have on the front page that he wasn't accused of wrong doing. They had no idea about the money laundering that I just laid out.

You know, they could have found out about this money laundering by not being so lazy and looking at the tapes.

BARTIROMO: I will say this, it's -- you cannot ignore the double standards of --

GIULIANI: Double standard?

BARTIROMO: -- of the way Mr. Trump's opponents treat the president. Right, we just came off all of this collusion nonsense for two years, where we're talking about unidentified sources and the president colluded and then we understand that it was absolutely a lot of nothing which we expected anyway.

GIULIANI: And this guy's story has changed now three times. And now it also turns out he's not a direct witness. I don't even know how he knows about it. He's got it all wrong. No money, no quid pro quo. According to the Ukrainians, no pressure. I mean, --

BARTIROMO: So, we know that Biden had this interaction in the Ukraine then there's China. I want to ask you about this because vice president did take Hunter Biden on Air Force Two and then -- to China.

GIULIANI: Well, let me figure -- let me figure out how the Democrats going to get out of this one. So the vice president flies his son, the guy that's drug challenged and flies him to China, yes. He negotiate --

BARTIROMO: While he's on a trip to go meet with --

GIULIANI: Serious trip. He's trying to talk China out of the Falkland Islands.

BARTIROMO: That's what the vice president is -- why the vice president is going to China.

GIULIANI: -- every one of his diplomatic missions including his one to -- his one to Baghdad where he couldn't get his status of forces, he failed (INAUDIBLE) He failed at every foreign policy issue he ever had, that's their Secretary of Defense, not mine.

So he goes there, he's negotiating with the Chinese. He doesn't tell anybody the kid is spending his time in the Bank of China. He fails with his negotiation with the Chinese. He blows it. Maybe he wanted to thank for him, I don't know but he failed. But Joe fails at everything so it's hard to say.

Eight days later there's a $1 billion check that goes into Hunter Biden's private equity fund, a private equity fund that I think made about $0.04 and you know the part is where, the son of the vice president of the United States, the stepson of the Secretary of State of the United States John Kerry and Whitey Bulger's nephew.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

GIULIANI: Tell me this isn't news.

BARTIROMO: And you know that Joe Biden and (INAUDIBLE) when he first -- when Joe Biden first cut on the scene --

GIULIANI: I just said Whitey Bulger, you don't think that would be on the front page of every newspaper if a Republican president?

BARTIROMO: But it's not, that's the thing.

GIULIANI: Don't tell me they aren't phony.

BARTIROMO: All of this does not smell right. I agree with that.

However, how are you going to get through and cut through all of the adversaries of this president that are putting it on the front page as if there were something improper there?

GIULIANI: I'm doing it, it takes some blood to do it but we're doing it.

BARTIROMO: Because remember when Joe Biden first ran for president, he said China's fine, no problem with China.

GIULIANI: Maria, that China thing happened three years ago, four years ago, it finally -- now I have another question. What kind of ethics standards do they have in the Obama administration?

Obama read this story about this kid who gets tossed out of the army for drugs, getting hired by the most crooked oligarch in Ukraine, Biden have a -- did Obama ever call Biden in and say what's going on, Joe? Don't they check conflicts?

BARTIROMO: There's another issue and I think Devin Nunes brought this up yesterday on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES". Should we have a precedent that the president of the free world's private calls with other world leaders are open to the public scrutiny.

GIULIANI: No, of course not.

BARTIROMO: That's another issue here.

GIULIANI: No, they shouldn't be open. But in any event, this can be open. I tell you, when the -- they're going to be -- well, they don't get embarrassed, you know.

When this turns out not to be true they're going to move on to did he have four parking tickets that he didn't pay.

BARTIROMO: Is there any way we're going to see accountability for things like the Clinton campaign financing foreign accusations against Mr. Trump, all of these things, the Russia collusion situation, where Hillary Clinton paid for the dossier. I mean, there's all this other stuff that the media refuses to focus on.

GIULIANI: If there's not an investigation of these two things, the five, six million that Hunter Biden got from a crooked Ukrainian company and the father getting him out in which there were at least four or five witness in Ukraine are ready to -- they've been ready to testify for a year. And our ambassador there was blocking them from coming to the United States. They've been trying to get this information to the FBI for a year.

There's also an FBI agent involved. The FBI agent who is investigating the allegations about dirt on the Trump campaign, she's now working for George Soros. She was working for George Soros back then. Soros' NGO was involved in this whole thing.

BARTIROMO: But are you going to be able to make the case to make sure to cut through all of this in the face of such skepticism about President Trump coming from the media and the Democrats.

I mean, going into 2020, this is going to -- things like this will keep coming up. How is the president going to --

GIULIANI: If they -- if they -- if they can talk their way out of the 1.5 billion, then we don't have a system of justice in the country anymore.

BARTIROMO: And people won't trust the DOJ unless we see accountability from Russia. I don't know --

GIULIANI: Do you know how much money Agnew got when he was in the --

BARTIROMO: We don't know.

GIULIANI: $10,000. $1.5 billion for the son of the vice president and the son of the Secretary of State is a massive Obama --

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. I am back with the personal attorney for President Trump, former New York City Mayor, Mayor Rudy Giuliani.

And Rudy, when we went to the break it was abrupt. You're basically saying you think this is a positive for President Trump because you're putting a spotlight on Biden.

GIULIANI: It's the only way you can get this out. I mean, the only way that they would cover this story is by punching the president in the face and then the president deflects the punch which he's done, the story has come way down from where it was and then he hits them with a right hand that's much more powerful than their punch.

BARTIROMO: But they're not covering it.

GIULIANI: And by the way, they're covering it. Yesterday --

BARTIROMO: They're not covering Biden and what Biden did to China and then Ukraine.

GIULIANI: Yes, they are. Every one of the newspapers had articles about it yesterday.

BARTIROMO: OK.

GIULIANI: Biden was asked about it for the first time on Saturday. Biden was asked about it on Sunday. You start asking Biden, he's going to fall apart.

And Maria, it's not over. There's a lot more evidence I'm going to put out. I put one out today, money laundering. I've got a bigger one for tomorrow, a big one for the day after.

And on China -- on China, if they can escape China, we literally don't have a system of justice left in this country. $1.5 billion when you are negotiating with China on sensitive issues and your family gets enriched with an investment in a private equity fund.

Now why did China give the money -- why would China give the money to a drug challenged private equity owner except to influence his father. They didn't make money on this.

BARTIROMO: Real quick, Adam Schiff wants to see --

GIULIANI: And the Obama administration did nothing about it.

BARTIROMO: Adam Schiff wants to see the whistleblower complaint. Why not send --

GIULIANI: I wouldn't give Adam Schiff anything. Adam Schiff said yesterday --

BARTIROMO: Why not? Why not just give the whistleblower complaint?

GIULIANI: Because you make it hard on these phonies. Adam Schiff yesterday said that if the president held back military aid and therefore he has to be impeached, but he didn't read the newspaper that day.

The story about holding back the military that now turns out to be untrue. That isn't part of the conversation. It was clarified. The whistleblower probably doesn't even know the conversation.

BARTIROMO: And no comment about when Adam Schiff is actually going to take a look at the wrongdoing done in 2016 in terms of Peter Strzok and Andrew McCabe. No comment there.

GIULIANI: I would never ever go in front of a judge that's fixed. Would you?

Well, Adam Schiff is fixed, he's completely dishonest. Yesterday he made a fool out of himself when he said the president has to be impeached because he held back military aid.

Two weeks ago the president gave the military aid and the conversation doesn't involve military aid.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will leave it there. You're expecting all of this to continue to be talked about in terms of what Hunter Biden did and you're not going to --

GIULIANI: They more they want to talk about Ukraine the better. Then I'd like to start talking about China.

BARTIROMO: And you're not going to give the whistleblower complaint to the Intel.

GIULIANI: It's not up to me. That's a matter of the government.

BARTIROMO: Rudy Giuliani, good to see you sir.

GIULIANI: That's their strategy, not mine.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Rudy Giuliani there.

Coming up, worries at WeWork, we're going to talk about it. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. More trouble for WeWork. Some company board members are now reportedly pushing CEO Adam Neumann out. Susan Li with the story right now, Susan.

LI: Big shareholder, Softbank apparently leading the charge with some of these directors looking to oust Adam Neumann, and this is after they delayed that IPO last week where the valuation was sliced by two-thirds and also allegations of drug use that came up in this Wall Street Journal report at the end of last week.

So Masa Son, the biggest shareholder in Softbank apparently losing their patience and wanting to move Adam Neumann on to a non-executive chairman role.

Now Adam Neumann before the IPO also there were allegations of misuse of funds and selling off his shares and borrowing against his stake in the company. So some say, well, maybe let's move him on, kind of like Travis Kalanick ahead of the Uber IPO, move him onto a nonexecutive role.

But there's a bit of a problem with this since we have Adam Neumann of course has -- he has the super voting rights and basically he can eliminate any proposal that comes up to the board. So whether or not you know, he will be leaving WeWork when it hits the market, if it hits the market this year, because there are doubts whether or not still IPO in 2019 at all.

BARTIROMO: Investors need to understand what super voting rights mean before they invest in a company.

LI: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: They need to understand this. I don't -- I don't know that everybody does.

FREEMAN: And it's interesting here because he's got this overwhelming control but he needs Softbank, he needs their money to keep going, doesn't he?

LI: Yes, well, you're burning $1.6 billion, that's the loss they had last year, that's pretty much equivalent to their revenue, those are not great metrics by the way when you're trying to sell shares to the market, right?

PAYNE: You know, and that's the big thing, right. Those super voting rights are great but when you need cash, you need cash and that's where, you know, Softbank to this point basically has the final say in my opinion.

PEEK: I understand, heard -- I was hearing an interview I think on another network about how basically panning all new IPOs using this as an example, I thought that was really out of -- you know, inappropriate.

(CROSSTALK)

PEEK: I mean, really. Exactly.

BARTIROMO: Susan, thank you.

LI: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you, Susan Li.

Still ahead the Trump campaign and the U.N., Press Secretary and Communications Director for President Trump and First Lady Melania Trump, Stephanie Grisham is here, next hour, MORNINGS WITH MARIA stay with us.

urn:contentItem:5WRR-09R1-JBHT-D01F-00000-00Interview with Rudy Giuliani; Ongoing Inquiry's Impact on President Trump; Congress Impeaching over Campaign Finance Violations; Bill Gates Talks about Foreign Aid; Impact of Global Climate Change; Washington Backlash Against Big Tech; Bill Gates on Microsoft's Race2018-12-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:24ZLexisNexisInterview with Rudy Giuliani; Ongoing Inquiry's Impact on President Trump; Congress Impeaching over Campaign Finance Violations; Bill Gates Talks about Foreign Aid; Impact of Global Climate Change; Washington Backlash Against Big Tech; Bill Gates on Microsoft's RaceLanhamFULL TEXT

CHRIS WALLACE, FOX NEWS HOST: I'm Chris Wallace.

A federal judge strikes down Obamacare, and President Trump's former fixer is sentenced to prison. Who in the president's inner circle is next to fall?

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Let me tell you, I never directed him to do anything wrong. Whatever he did, he did on his own.

WALLACE: What do we know about President Trump's involvement in hush money payments of two women during the 2016 campaign? And what does Michael Cohen's cooperation mean for the special counsel investigation? We'll ask the president's lead lawyer, Rudy Giuliani.

Then --

TRUMP: I am proud to shut down the government for border security, Chuck. I will take the mantle. I will be the one to shut it down. I'm not going to blame you for it.

WALLACE: The president deals with a divided Washington and a possible government shutdown over his border wall.

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D), CALIFORNIA: Perhaps he doesn't understand people leave their paychecks.

WALLACE: We'll ask our Sunday panel if we're headed for compromise or confrontation.

Plus --

BILL GATES, GATES FOUNDATSION: The U.S.'s engagement in Africa and around the world, there are many reasons we should maintain that.

WALLACE: We'll talk with Bill Gates, co-chair of the Gates Foundation about what he feels is a shrinking U.S. role in dealing with global poverty and public health.

All right now on "FOX News Sunday".

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WALLACE: And hello again from FOX News in Washington.

We begin with breaking news. A federal judge has ruled the entire Affordable Care Act invalid. Obamacare will remain in place pending appeal and both President Trump and Democrats are calling for Congress to pass new legislation. We'll get to all that a little later.

But first, the president is already dealing with a possible government shutdown that's now just five days away. Meanwhile, prosecutors are producing more of the evidence that led former members of Mr. Trump's inner circle to plead guilty, evidence that implicates the president.

Let's get the latest from Kevin Corke live at the White House -- Kevin.

KEVIN CORKE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Chris, even for an administration accustomed to seismic shifts in the news cycle, it was without a doubt a tumultuous week. But few headlines could prove as potentially damaging to the Trump White House than those involving former members of the president's inner circle.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CORKE: Three of whom are facing time in prison for a variety of misdeeds, but none involving so-called Russian collusion. Former national security adviser, General Michael Flynn, faces sentencing Tuesday for lying to federal investigators. The special counsel's office recommending he get no jail time even as it has faced charges that the general was entrapped and inappropriately questioned.

Meanwhile, in his first televised interview since being sentenced to three years behind bar, the president's former fixer, attorney Michael Cohen, claimed he repeatedly lied for Mr. Trump over the years and he would set up payments to women to help aid his 2016 campaign, a claim strongly denied by the White House.

TRUMP: I will take the mantle of shutting down and I'm going to shut it down for border security.

(CROSSTALK)

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D), NEW YORK: But we believe you shouldn't shut it down.

CORKE: An Oval Office meeting with leading Democrats this week did little to quell fears of a potential partial government shutdown over the president's insistence that there would be funding for a border wall, something Democrats say they won't pay for. A work stoppage that could come in a week in which backers of the Affordable Care Act, Obamacare, consider their next move in the wake of a federal judge's ruling that the law is unconstitutional.

TRUMP: -- that the Supreme Court upholds, we'll be sitting down with the Democrats and we will get great health care for our people. Let's say repeal and replace.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

I think that what's unfortunate here is that you have what begins as a special prosecutor focus on collusion in Russia. And as Julie just said, it's about every part of his life. We end up saying, instead of investigating a crime, we're investigating a person. And Republicans and civil libertarians used to oppose that motion after Iran Contra. Then they fell in love with it during the Whitewater years because they said it was a land deal but it became something about an affair with an intern.

And it's a problem. It's a problem where we have prosecutors going all over. And I think --

WALLACE: But how about -- how about the argument that is made, gee, we didn't hear Republicans complain about it when it happened to Bill Clinton?

SHORT: I agree 100 percent. I'm saying -- I'm saying Republicans as well have been hypocritical on this. There used to be a group of strong, civil libertarians who would recognize the problem of special prosecutors. And -- probably this is now the -- what's been born of that fruit.

WALLACE: All right, so far the only alleged crime that the president is specifically linked to is not collusion, is not obstruction of justice, it involves campaign finance violations, alleged campaign finance violations.

Here is how Democratic Congressman Jerry Nadler, the incoming chair of the House Judiciary Committee, responded to that this week.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JERRY NADLER (D-NY), HOUSE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE, RANKING MEMBER: Well, they would be impeachable offenses. Whether they are important enough to justify an impeachment is a different question.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WALLACE: Brit, how persuaded are you that if President Trump directed these payments, these hush money payments, as Michael Cohen says he did, that it was a campaign finance violation on his part, a criminal violation? And, two, what do you think of the likelihood that the House and the wisdom of the House proceeding to impeachment on campaign finance violation?

BRIT HUME, FOX NEWS SENIOR POLITICAL ANALYST: I think it's a little hard to imagine a president being impeached for a campaign finance violation. Most of these violations are handled as civil matters and result in fines. And they are, you know, widespread, rampant. Obama had a -- the Obama campaign had to pay a big fine.

I don't -- I just don't think the House of Representatives, even such ardent Democrats as Jerry Nadler, will go there. The greater worry is that some other charge comes out when Mueller finally gets his ore in with his report and says whatever he says. And that, I think, Chris, raises an intriguing question, which is this, how far will these House investigations go if Mueller doesn't find something very serious about the president? My thought is, it probably takes the wind out of their sails, but we'll have to wait and see. But, on balance, I don't think campaign finance is going to dislodge him.

WALLACE: When you look at all of this and, you know, as we say, there is still no hard evidence of collusion, no hard evidence of obstruction of justice, but the wall do seem to be moving in on the president on a lot of fronts.

HUME: Well, I don't think the Mueller report is likely to be -- to sing the president's praises. But that's not what he needs. What he needs is kind of an -- of a -- of a report that says, you know does not outline some major crime. And if that happens, I mean I think it changes the atmosphere dramatically, both legally and politically, because I think it's -- and if he is vindicated on no collusion, which is what he's been saying, I don't think the -- I've never thought that collusion was the central point of this investigation.

Remember, when it started, Chris, it was a counterintelligence investigation with the FBI acting as an intelligence agency to determine what Russia actually did. And if you go back and look at the letter authorizing Mueller's appointment, it says -- it mentions that it picks up that investigation and then says, he's also authorized to find out if there was collaboration between the two. That was always a subset of the overall investigation. And if it turns out to be a subset with no crime alleged in the final report, I think it's a huge boost for the president.

WALLACE: Juan.

JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS POLITICAL ANALYST: Well, I think the Democratic base is so inflamed by Trump, by his behavior overall, I think they -- they would think that Democrats weren't, in fact, holding up to their constitutional responsivities if they did not consider impeachment. So you get the --

WALLACE: Even on campaign finance violations?

WILLIAMS: Well, I mean, what we -- what did we learn this week? He wants to say it's just Michael Cohen making these outrageous claims because Cohen wants a better deal from the prosecutors. But, in fat, we hear from David Packer at "National Enquirer," same thing happened. We hear from "The Wall Street Journal," the president was in the room. So if -- potentially he would be an unindicted coconspirator while his president because nobody thinks you can indict the president. But that doesn't mean that you can't go to the Congress and say, let's look at this and see --

WALLACE: Do you really think that would be wise for Democrats to do? And this -- this is speculative.

WILLIAMS: Well, that's a separate issue. That's a separate issue.

WALLACE: OK. Well, that's my question, though.

WILLIAMS: OK. Well, if the question was --

WALLACE: Would it be wise for them to do it if that's all that there is?

WILLIAMS: Well, I don't think that's -- no. And I think that what you're going to see, and you already see this from, by the way, Jerry Nadler, but also from Nancy Pelosi, Chuck Schumer, as the say, they're not interested right now. But the base of the party, is what I was trying to say to you, Chris, is going to be putting pressure there because they think that, in fact, Democrats had been too docile in dealing with Trump and they want -- they want them to come and have the --

WALLACE: They want blood?

WILLIAMS: Well, because, guess what, you've saw a blue wave, 40 seats switch hands, and the number -- you know, health care was clearly important. But also a check on Trump was very important to voters.

WALLACE: And every indication is -- everybody keeps saying this investigation is going to be over the end of the year.

WILLIAMS: I don't see it.

WALLACE: I always say, pick the over, right?

PACE: Right. We -- we don't know what else Mueller has. I think this could go well into next year and really line up with some of these congressional investigation.

WALLACE: Thank you, panel.

Up next we sit down with Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates, head of the Gates Foundation. In the era of America first, he worries about a shrinking U.S. role in dealing with global poverty and public health.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WALLACE: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is the world's largest private charitable fund, giving $46 billion in grants since its founding in 2000 and literally saving millions of lives. The Microsoft co-founder came to Washington this week to make the case for American leadership and the need for foreign aid in the era of America first. When we sat down at the Chamber of Commerce, that's where we began.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BILL GATES, MICROSOFT CO-FOUNDER AND PHILANTHROPIST: There was a recommendation by the executive branch to make fairly substantial cuts U.S. aid budget. And, fortunately, the Congress took that proposal, which would have meant cutting people off from those HIV medicines, and they decided to maintain the foreign aid levels.

WALLACE: Your wife Melinda recently talked about -- and I want to quote her directly -- how incredibly disappointing it is to see U.S. leadership deteriorating and the view of the U.S. deteriorating because of some of the egregious things that have been said by this current administration. What's she talking about?

GATES: I hope I know. The -- I think the particular episode there was talking about Africa and the conditions in Africa in a -- not in a positive way. Sort of characterizing the entire continent. But, in any case --

WALLACE: Your talk about the blank countries?

GATES: Exactly. In the U.S. engagement in Africa and around the world, there are many reasons we should maintain that. Just a pure security point of view alone would justify this level of expenditure.

Now, for many people, the humanitarian part of it is also there and that part is dramatic. And so it is disappointing when it feels like the U.S. is being short-term and the U.S. is only thinking about its interest in a very narrow way and not being the leader that says, now, we -- you know, we are going to help these countries get so that they can -- can take care of themselves.

WALLACE: The president's mantra is America first. You seem to be suggesting that in terms of America's interests you've got to look a long way beyond America first.

GATES: Well, I think that the broad definition of our interests, including investing in allies and not viewing every transaction as one that we have to maximize our benefit, taking, you know, world institutions and have them just focus on the United States. What we did, in terms of the post-World War II institutions has been a fantastic thing. That included having a common view of the future with our western allies.

If you really follow that line of thinking, the idea of helping Africa, of working on an HIV vaccine to stop the AIDS crisis, you just wouldn't do it. And -- and yet I feel, even in that narrow framework of, OK, I only care about what -- how U.S. citizens do, even in that framework, these institutions, these alliances, these investments in innovation are overwhelmingly smart things to do.

WALLACE: Since the year 2000, a billion people have lifted themselves from what you define as extreme poverty. And you say that the first wave was in China and the second wave was in India. Before we get to places where the wave hasn't hit yet, what happened in those places?

GATES: One of the first things you want to do in these countries is raise agricultural productivity. All of the Asian miracles, even going back to Taiwan and Japan, South Korea, involved more than tripling agricultural output per person so you could free up that labor and move it into the cities. And if you had the right infrastructure, educational investment, then you've got a manufacturing sector of the economy and slowly but surely you'd get a very large middle class.

WALLACE: You talk about the successes, the waves in China and India, and then there's Africa. You say that by 2050, 86 percent -- 86 percent of the extremely poor people in the world will live in Africa and, in fact, 40 percent will live in just two countries, the Democratic Republic of Congo and Nigeria.

What's holding them back?

GATES: They're starting at very low levels of infrastructure, very low level of property. And one of the things that drives those numbers you mentioned is the very high population growth. And so they account for double the portions of births you'd expect. By the end of the century, the majority of births in the world will take place in Africa.

Africa has to demand our attention. That's where extreme poverty is still tough. That's where stability is difficult to achieve. And, you know, we've got to go after things like these neglected diseases, malaria. We've got to help them with infrastructure. It's really, in terms of our humanity of helping the poorest, Africa's where we'll be most tested.

WALLACE: How do you even begin to address these concentrations of misery?

GATES: Well, one of the great achievements in development history was what was called the green revolution where new varieties of the cereal (ph) crops, corn, which everyone else calls maize, rice and wheat. In a period where people thought India would experience mass starvation because the agricultural output went up, they were actually able to improve the nutrition even when their population was growing. We need to do that same thing for Africa.

WALLACE: It seems that climate change could be the accelerant to all of the bad things in terms of agricultural productivity, global health, instability, extreme poverty. Talk about that.

GATES: Yes. For a country like the U.S., that's northern, you know, climate change will change things. We'll have more hot days, more forest fires. But it's not a threat to our survival.

In Africa, where you are completely dependent on the rain coming, whereas there been in the past about one out of 12 years you'll have a failed harvest, the prediction is that we be closer to one out of four years because of the higher temperature and the -- the -- unfortunately, with climate change, you -- not only is it hotter, but the rain comes all at once, or it doesn't come for long periods of time. So if you want to say, where are you going to get millions of deaths because of climate change between now and the end of the century, you don't look to the United States. Yes, you'll have some forest fires and there will be some deaths. But the -- the significant numbers are in these very, very poor countries because of the subsistence farming.

WALLACE: What do you say to those who say it's not climate change, it's weather, and that the -- the man -- the human component is questionable?

GATES: That's impressive if somebody can say that out loud. The --the amount of --

WALLACE: Have you been -- have you been to Washington?

GATES: The amount of CO2 in the atmosphere is a super measurable thing. It's important not to over claim what we know because that undermines the whole discussion., But the general warming and the mechanism of that warming has to do with CO2 and methane emissions. That's -- that's really not a question.

WALLACE: I want to talk to you about toilets. Since 2011, the Gates Foundation has launched to reinvent the toilet challenge. Explain, one, why that's so important, and, two, again, dealing with the specifics, what have been some of your successes and failures along the way?

GATES: In many of these poor countries, the capital cost of building that sewer, it's just never going to happen. And so the solution would be to, instead of using that sewer, to have something in the toilet itself, which is essentially the processing facility. We have ten different universities whose designs we funded. So we put in several hundred million dollars. And now we've gotten it to the point where we have a lot of commercial companies who say, OK, that approach looks promising.

Now, the price of this toilet, that does the processing, is still ten times more expensive. It's about, you know, $10,000 per toilet right now. We need to get it into these tough parts, the slums of these African cities. We need it to be more like a thousand dollars.

WALLACE: I want to ask about your -- your old job. There's something of a backlash here in Washington against big tech. The growing feeling in Washington is that big tech does not do enough to protect users' privacy and that it shows political bias. Do you see merit in either of those arguments?

GATES: I went through an episode in the late '90s where Microsoft was subject to government investigation.

WALLACE: We remember.

GATES: And so in a way this is -- in a small way now it's less Microsoft now, but it's broad.

Yes, the government should be talking to these companies about what they do. There's nothing inappropriate.

I was naive. I didn't have an office in Washington, D.C. I thought that was a good thing and I even bragged about it. I later came to regret that.

So these -- I'm sure these guys are learning better than I did that they need to come back here and start a dialogue. And there will be new types of regulations for these companies.

WALLACE: And you don't have a problem with that? I mean you think that's appropriate?

GATES: Well, the notion that there will be privacy regulations, that makes a lot of sense. The notion that this ability to identify anyone that were going to think about how do businesses get to use that and how does the government use that, it makes a lot of sense.

WALLACE: Apple, Amazon and Microsoft are right now jockeying for which is going to be the most highly valued company in the world in terms of market capitalization. At the close of the market on Friday, Microsoft was number one at over $800 billion, Apple, $799.5 billion. Does that give you any pleasure?

GATES: You know, when I was starting Microsoft in my 20s, the idea that we could create a company that was -- you know, would beat IBM, you know, because they were the big monolith and, you know, we understood software and they didn't. And we believed in these cute, small machines to empower individuals and they believed in these big machines. It was kind of mythic that we were going to beat IBM.

By the time Microsoft valuation passed IBM, which is now, you know, 15 years ago, it didn't feel like that big of a victory. And so you really -- it's really better to define yourself by an aspiration. You know, can software improve education? Can software help, you know, medical care costs in the U.S. just keep going up dramatically? Can software play a role there?.

So, yes, I'm very proud of Microsoft and the vision that software and technology would make a big thing. You know, it's led to the most valuable, the five most valuable companies being these tech companies. So I do think it's an vindication (ph) of the importance of technology, which now is coming with a lot of responsibilities as well.

WALLACE: Bill, it's an honor to talk to you again.

GATES: Thank you.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WALLACE: And if you want to learn more about the remarkable work Bill and Melinda Gates are doing, you can find their link at foxnewssunday.com.

Up next, a final word.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WALLACE: Stay tuned to this station and Fox News Channel for the latest on a potential end of year government shutdown.

And that's it for today. Have a great week and we'll see you next FOX NEWS SUNDAY.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WRR-09R1-JBHT-D01N-00000-00Interview with Rudy Giuliani; Ongoing Inquiry's Impact on President Trump; Congress Impeaching over Campaign Finance Violations; Bill Gates Talks about Foreign Aid; Impact of Global Climate Change; Washington Backlash Against Big Tech; Bill Gates on Microsoft's Race2018-12-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:23ZLexisNexisInterview with Rudy Giuliani; Ongoing Inquiry's Impact on President Trump; Congress Impeaching over Campaign Finance Violations; Bill Gates Talks about Foreign Aid; Impact of Global Climate Change; Washington Backlash Against Big Tech; Bill Gates on Microsoft's RaceLanhamFULL TEXT

CHRIS WALLACE, FOX NEWS HOST: I'm Chris Wallace.

A federal judge strikes down Obamacare, and President Trump's former fixer is sentenced to prison. Who in the president's inner circle is next to fall?

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Let me tell you, I never directed him to do anything wrong. Whatever he did, he did on his own.

WALLACE: What do we know about President Trump's involvement in hush money payments of two women during the 2016 campaign? And what does Michael Cohen's cooperation mean for the special counsel investigation? We'll ask the president's lead lawyer, Rudy Giuliani.

Then --

TRUMP: I am proud to shut down the government for border security, Chuck. I will take the mantle. I will be the one to shut it down. I'm not going to blame you for it.

WALLACE: The president deals with a divided Washington and a possible government shutdown over his border wall.

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D), CALIFORNIA: Perhaps he doesn't understand people leave their paychecks.

WALLACE: We'll ask our Sunday panel if we're headed for compromise or confrontation.

Plus --

BILL GATES, GATES FOUNDATSION: The U.S.'s engagement in Africa and around the world, there are many reasons we should maintain that.

WALLACE: We'll talk with Bill Gates, co-chair of the Gates Foundation about what he feels is a shrinking U.S. role in dealing with global poverty and public health.

All right now on "FOX News Sunday".

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WALLACE: And hello again from FOX News in Washington.

We begin with breaking news. A federal judge has ruled the entire Affordable Care Act invalid. Obamacare will remain in place pending appeal and both President Trump and Democrats are calling for Congress to pass new legislation. We'll get to all that a little later.

But first, the president is already dealing with a possible government shutdown that's now just five days away. Meanwhile, prosecutors are producing more of the evidence that led former members of Mr. Trump's inner circle to plead guilty, evidence that implicates the president.

Let's get the latest from Kevin Corke live at the White House -- Kevin.

KEVIN CORKE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Chris, even for an administration accustomed to seismic shifts in the news cycle, it was without a doubt a tumultuous week. But few headlines could prove as potentially damaging to the Trump White House than those involving former members of the president's inner circle.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CORKE: Three of whom are facing time in prison for a variety of misdeeds, but none involving so-called Russian collusion. Former national security adviser, General Michael Flynn, faces sentencing Tuesday for lying to federal investigators. The special counsel's office recommending he get no jail time even as it has faced charges that the general was entrapped and inappropriately questioned.

Meanwhile, in his first televised interview since being sentenced to three years behind bar, the president's former fixer, attorney Michael Cohen, claimed he repeatedly lied for Mr. Trump over the years and he would set up payments to women to help aid his 2016 campaign, a claim strongly denied by the White House.

TRUMP: I will take the mantle of shutting down and I'm going to shut it down for border security.

(CROSSTALK)

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D), NEW YORK: But we believe you shouldn't shut it down.

CORKE: An Oval Office meeting with leading Democrats this week did little to quell fears of a potential partial government shutdown over the president's insistence that there would be funding for a border wall, something Democrats say they won't pay for. A work stoppage that could come in a week in which backers of the Affordable Care Act, Obamacare, consider their next move in the wake of a federal judge's ruling that the law is unconstitutional.

TRUMP: -- that the Supreme Court upholds, we'll be sitting down with the Democrats and we will get great health care for our people. Let's say repeal and replace.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CORKE: That ruling by District Court Judge Reed O'Connor, Chris, does not impact Obamacare recipients in the short term, but it does set up a potential high court battle and that is a debate White House officials would love to have -- Chris.

WALLACE: Kevin Corke reporting from the White House -- Kevin, thanks.

WALLACE: And joining me now from New York, the president's lead lawyer, Rudy Giuliani.

Mayor, welcome back to "FOX News Sunday".

RUDY GUILIANI, LEAD LAWYER, DONALD TRUMP: Thank you very much. Thank you -- thank you, Chris.

WALLACE: Let's start with Michael Cohen's allegation that President Trump directed him to commit a criminal campaign finance violation. Here first was the president and then Mr. Cohen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I never directed him to do anything wrong. Whatever he did, he did on his own. He's a lawyer. A lawyer who represents a client is supposed to do the right thing.

MICHAEL COHEN, FORMER LAWYER, DONALD TRUMP: He directed me to make the payments, he directed me to become involved in these matters.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WALLACE: Question. Did Mr. Trump direct Michael Cohen to pay off these two women or not?

GIULIANI: No, the truth is actually what Cohen testified to under oath before Congress and what he repeated numerous times on surreptitious tape recordings that he made, which is that the president didn't know about this until some time into it, he did find out about it and eventually reimburse him. But, you know, this is a hard thing to do, but lawyers do this all the time.

But, Chris, even if it were true, it's not a crime. The payment -- the payment of money in a situation like this has been covered in the Edwards case. Not only the acquittal and hung jury in the Edwards case, but the fact that the FEC looked at those Edwards violations and determined they weren't violations --

(CROSSTALK)
